tropeNotes: [Accentuate the Negative](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AccentuateTheNegative): After learning that he was originally created to destroy all life on Gaia, he believes that he doesn't deserve to be friends with the same people he was originally supposed to destroy. He also ends up agreeing with Steiner's earlier statements about him being nothing but trouble, despite Steiner long since growing out of that viewpoint.
[Accidental Pervert](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AccidentalPervert): He inadvertently touches Garnet's butt while both of them are climbing a ladder. The lady is not amused.
[The Ace](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAce): He's intelligent, cultured, street-smart, handsome, and very capable in battle.

[All-Loving Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllLovingHero): He lives his live by the simple question, "[Do I need a reason to help people?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterCatchphrase)" and variations thereof. Those who seek to hurt innocents are the only ones who earn his wrath.

[Animal Motifs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimalMotifs): Monkeys. [Justified Trope](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustifiedTrope), since it's a [Lions and Tigers and Humans... Oh, My!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LionsAndTigersAndHumansOhMy) universe.

[Anti-Anti-Christ](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiAntichrist): He was created for the sole reason of destroying all life on Gaia, but because of Kuja's actions he is left as an infant on the very same world that he was meant to destroy. Learning this horrible truth from his creator, as well as having his "soul" ripped out of him, becomes a massive [Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD) for our hero. He only recovers when his friends demonstrate [The Power of Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePowerOfFriendship) and remind him "[You Are Not Alone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreNotAlone)."
[Artificial Human](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtificialHuman): He's a Genome, like a lot of beings on Terra, but a special one. Garland created him to be an angel of death.

[Awful Truth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AwfulTruth): The revelation of his Antichrist origins and his inability to stop Garland when they meet hits him hard. For a while, he starts acting [way out of character to his friends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OOCIsSeriousBusiness).

[Badass Boast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBoast): To Garland: "I AM the new Angel of Death! Yours!" Also counts as [Calling the Old Man Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CallingTheOldManOut), after Garland told Zidane that he was created on Terra.

[Belated Love Epiphany](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BelatedLoveEpiphany): Zidane only realizes that he loves Garnet after she is crowned queen (and thus becomes seemingly inaccessible for him). Before that, he's all playful and flirting, but doesn't think it's for real.
[BFS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS): His thief swords, especially the Ultima Weapon, [get quite big](http://www.dissidia-france.com/img/personnages/exm/refs/zidane.png)◊.
[Big Brother Instinct](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBrotherInstinct): He sees Vivi almost as a surrogate little brother, encouraging him to come out of his shell and being very protective of him.
[Big Brother Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBrotherMentor): He looks out for Vivi from early on and helps him understand the world.

[Break the Cutie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakTheCutie): The end of Disc 3. Garland attempts to rip his soul out after revealing to Zidane his true origins as Gaia's destroyer. The revelation that he was meant to be what Kuja is now shakes him hard.

[Cain and Abel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CainAndAbel): His relationship to his older brother Kuja is [complicated to say the least](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ZigZaggingTrope). They are enemies, then they are both against their father, then they are enemies again, but Zidane still makes sure he doesn't die alone.
[Cannot Spit It Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CannotSpitItOut): His *true* feelings, that is. By the time he's actually fallen for Garnet, he can't bring himself to tell her.

tropeName: Can't Act Perverted Toward a Love Interest
tropeNotes: [Can't Act Perverted Toward a Love Interest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CantActPervertedTowardALoveInterest): He constantly flirts with Garnet throughout the game, but backs off slightly after Disc 2, when he realizes he loves her.

[Chivalrous Pervert](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChivalrousPervert): His overworld sprite has him turning his head in the direction of passing females! Is he checking if they need help, or just checking them out? You decide.

[Chronic Hero Syndrome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChronicHeroSyndrome): His heroic streak is played for drama during disc 3. He's always helping people as part of his efforts to conceal his own problems. Mutually accepting the help of his friends in return doesn't come easy to him, which is why after his [Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD) he brushes off his allies and tries to continue on alone.
[Cultured Warrior](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CulturedWarrior): He's a warrior, he's a thief, and he's quite a good *actor!* And possibly a musician as well, considering how much he knows about music.
[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): Zidane is very snarky when he wants to be, mostly towards Steiner on the first disc and then towards Quina, Amarant and sometimes Freya.

[Devious Daggers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeviousDaggers): Favors [Dual Wielding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualWield) daggers, fitting for a thief by trade and rogue by inclination. His "thief swords", [double-bladed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoubleWeapon) spear or staff-like weapons, seem less fitting until you realize that most of them are [synthesized](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItemCrafting) by [combining two daggers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprovisedWeapon).

[Dogged Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoggedNiceGuy): He's constantly trying to earn Garnet's favor. At first, she's too naive to realize what he's doing, and later has caught on to his behavior and knows not to fall for it.

[Doom Magnet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoomMagnet): To the point that [the Console RPG Cliche List](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ConsoleRPGCliches25To48) named these tropes after him. Surprisingly, it all happens for plot reasons (at least in theory) and [it's never commented on by anyone in-game](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenreBlind).
QUOTE  Zidane's Curse: An unlucky condition in which every location in the game will coincidentally wind up being destroyed just after the hero arrives.

[Double Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoubleWeapon): He can use two completely different kinds of weapons. One of them (and probably among the strongest weapons) is a stick with two blades on each side.
[Drowning My Sorrows](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrowningMySorrows): At the beginning of Disc 3 he's bemoaning his fate in a tavern. If he's not getting wasted, it certainly looks like it.
[Dual Wielding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualWielding): One kind of weapon he can use is a couple of knives in [Reverse Grip](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReverseGrip).

[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): To Djidane in the French version, in order to avoid confusion with French soccer player Zinedine Zidane. In the Spanish version, he's called "Yitán", for exactly the same reason, and the same happens in the Italian version, where his name is changed in to Gidan0. Zidane was originally named Jitan.

[The Dulcinea Effect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDulcineaEffect):
QUOTE  "Yeah. She's cute, and she's in trouble. What do I need to think about?"

[Establishing Character Moment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EstablishingCharacterMoment): The two core parts of his personality, a love of the ladies and his drive to protect them, happen at two different moments.
    - When he sees Garnet captured by the plant monster's minion, he enters into Trance, which only happens when one is feeling incredibly strong emotions. And for comparison, Steiner (Garnet's sworn protector and fiercely loyal subject) didn't change. - It doesn't happen until about an hour or two into the game, but one memorable moment (which, incidentally, took place during the first instance of Zidane's leitmotif playing in the BGM) firmly establishes that Zidane isn't just a [Lovable Rogue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LovableRogue), he's also [something else](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChivalrousPervert) as well...
QUOTE "Ooo, soft..."

[Everyone Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneHasStandards): Zidane is unashamedly perverted towards girls, but will always respect their boundaries. After the...[incident](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AccidentalPervert) involving Garnet and Zidane getting onto the Cargo Ship, it's made out to be an accident on his part and he awkwardly tries to apologize. He is also offended when Steiner accuses Zidane of "touching" Garnet when everyone fell unconscious in the Ice Cavern due to the work of Black Waltz 1.

[Experienced Protagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExperiencedProtagonist): What sets him apart from everyone else in his party (especially Garnet) is that he's been on several adventures in the past—none as grand as this one, but enough that he is keenly aware of what needs to be done. He also has many connections, friends and even enemies throughout the world, including Freya and Amarant, which plays a part in their motivations to join his party.

[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): He is based on, and has many parallelisms to, [Son Goku](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/DragonBall). Both are members of a monkey-like race from a destroyed planet and are sent to their current one with the intent of destroying it but ended up being its protector. Both have an elder brother as an antagonist and a princess as their [Love Interest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoveInterest). Even Zidane's [Trance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperMode) form looks similar to Goku's [Super Saiyan 4](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Anime/DragonBallGT).

[Genre Savvy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenreSavvy): As a theater actor and veteran adventurer, Zidane is quite astute when it comes to plot observations. He considers himself the hero of the journey long before the other characters take him seriously about it and justifies many of his more risky and daring moments by proclaiming himself to be [The Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHero) of this adventure with the appropriate amount of [Plot Armor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlotArmor). This [contrasts him with Kuja](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil), who is just as savvy, but embraces the role of a villain.

[Gentleman Thief](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GentlemanThief): He's cultured, friendly, and has no problem casually swiping valuables from civilians. This is probably one of the few *Final Fantasy* titles where [Kleptomaniac Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KleptomaniacHero) is in-character for the protagonist.
[Grim Reaper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrimReaper): Garland created him to be an angel of death that inflicted destruction and led the departing souls to him.
[Handsome Lech](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HandsomeLech): Good looking, and always thinking of girls.

[Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD): Gets struck with one at a [critical point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhamEpisode) in the game when he learns the [Awful Truth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AwfulTruth) about his origin. He even refuses his friends because how could they be friends if he is meant to be their killer?

[He's Back!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HesBack): After every one of his friends, and lastly Dagger, call him out on his mindset after the [Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD), he comes back to his original personality. Their refusal to leave him even knowing what he is helps rebuild him.

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): A far more complex character than he initially seems. It's lampshaded/played for laughs when he wonders if Garnet has finally fallen for him after he let on to her about this.

[Honor Before Reason](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HonorBeforeReason): His Protect Girls ability, depending on your party composition. It makes sense if [Garnet and/or Eiko](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SquishyWizard) are the only ladies in the party, but he'll even take hits for Freya, and is coded to do the same for the similarly bulky Beatrix, even if [there's no opportunity for this to ever happen without hacking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DevelopersForesight), who wears heavy armor compared to his and is likely always in the back row.

[Hypocrite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypocrite): He chastises Amarant for running off alone in Ispen's Castle and tells him that everyone works together as a team. Later on in Terra, after learning the truth about his origins and having part of his soul sucked out, Zidane pushes everyone away and insists he needs to do things alone. [Amarant rightfully calls out Zidane on this](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero), though Zidane eventually bounces back and apologizes.
[Keet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Keet): He's very energetic and playful most of the time.

[KidAnova](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KidAnova): Zidane being sixteen years old, his sex drive isn't out of place at all, but people not used to the [Super-Deformed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperDeformed) art style thought he was much younger.

[Ladykiller in Love](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadykillerInLove): Although Zidane flirts with other women through most of the game, he falls hard for Garnet and eventually realizes that she's his true love.

[Lightning Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightningBruiser): He has the highest Agility among all the characters, and has the second highest Strength as well as excellent defense, so Zidane will easily be one of the best party members. [Good thing the game requires he be in the party most of the time](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CantDropTheHero).

[Little Bit Beastly](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LittleBitBeastly): His monkey tail. Being that this title is full of such diverse characters and races, it isn't that noticeable. Which makes the reveal that he's a Genome much more surprising, and then you realize no one else you've met so far has had a tail like his.
[Look Behind You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LookBehindYou): His "What's That?!" Skill has him distract the enemy long enough to maneuver the party into a Back Attack against the enemy.
[Lovable Rogue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LovableRogue): Cheerful, wise-cracking, and happy to inform you he's living on the wrong side of the law and enjoys that lifestyle.

[My Friends... and Zoidberg](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyFriendsAndZoidberg): After the second escape from Alexandria, Dagger worries about the friends they left behind. Zidane assures her that they can handle things on their own, because they're "the best dragon knight of Burmecia, the female general of Alexandria...and [Rusty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VitriolicBestBuds)."

[Named After Somebody Famous](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NamedAfterSomebodyFamous): [Zinedine Zidane](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zinedine_Zidane), French [football](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/UsefulNotes/AssociationFootball) player who won [The World Cup](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/UsefulNotes/TheWorldCup) in 1998.

[Never Got to Say Goodbye](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverGotToSayGoodbye): A variant. Zidane gave his farewell to his friends before  (SPOILER) rescuing Kuja  after the [Final Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBattle) thinking he could die but actually survived. However, he was the only one not there when Vivi died which is the reason the latter addresses the game's [Epilogue Letter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EpilogueLetter) mainly to him.

[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy): He may not always be polite, but he's always friendly. To elaborate, unlike Cloud and Squall who shut people out at first, Zidane is always willing to make new friends but many characters commit on how insensitive he can be and a bit crass.

[Noodle Incident](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoodleIncident): Early in the game, Zidane was telling Dagger about one of his "adventures" until Dagger points out that Vivi hasn't come back (having been kidnapped).

["Not So Different" Remark](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoDifferentRemark):
    - Zidane secretly empathizes with Vivi *heavily*. As Vivi struggles to come to terms with his identity as a [Living Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LivingWeapon) and how he was created, it secretly reminded Zidane of his own journey to find out where he came from. (SPOILER) This comes full circle when Zidane learns that he's the most powerful [Living Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LivingWeapon) of them all. - In the ending, Zidane says the reason he (SPOILER) risks his life to save Kuja is that Zidane would probably have done *everything* Kuja would have done if their roles were reversed.
[Prehensile Tail](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrehensileTail): His tail is prehensile, although he only took advantage of this once, to hang from the rafters of the pilot's cabin of an Airship.

[The Social Expert](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSocialExpert): Zidane goes beyond being a [Lovable Rogue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LovableRogue). He demonstrates high emotional intelligence and reads and acts upon the personalities of multiple characters. He challenges Steiner's [rigid view of his queen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LawfulStupid), and Dagger's naivete. He works to encourage and mentor Vivi, and quickly determines that Eiko is lonely and seeking companionship.

[Stepford Smiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StepfordSmiler): He's very insecure and lonely, having no memories of his past and no real family aside from Tantalus. The reason he's so friendly and outgoing is to conceal the fact.

[Super Prototype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperPrototype): As the "Angel of Death" Genome he's implied to be one of the strongest of them all and the only one designed to be born as a baby and grow naturally with a normal human lifespan. He's not quite as powerful as Kuja individually but that's suggested to be because Zidane was raised and trained to be a thief rather than trained to use powerful magic like Kuja and Garland meaning he can only access that kind of power in Trance.
[Tomato in the Mirror](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TomatoInTheMirror): He's a Genome, an artificial lifeform that could have been working with Kuja.
[Trapped in Another World](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrappedInAnotherWorld): His whole life was being stranded on a world other than his birth place.
[Weapon Twirling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeaponTwirling): When equipped with the double bladed polearm, he does in his [Victory Pose](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VictoryPose).

[Wise Beyond Their Years](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WiseBeyondTheirYears): Despite being only 16 and younger than the majority of *Final Fantasy* heroes, he's very mature and intelligent. As well, while some of the other heroes are emotionally crippled due to their self-doubt and insecurities, Zidane copes with his by acting overly friendly and cheerful. It, of course, still leads to eventual problems, but for the most part he's much better adjusted than some of the heroes several years older than him.

[You Are Not Alone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreNotAlone): After he discovers why he was created, it takes all of his friends showing him they are still by his side to make him snap out of his [Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD).
[Artificial Human](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtificialHuman): Like all other black mages, he was created in a factory as a weapon of war.

[Awesome, but Impractical](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AwesomeButImpractical): While Vivi is one of the flashier characters, having most of the character development, and with spells like doomsday and flare, and subjectively being the most adorable, most players will have a tough time finding a spot for him in a party. Given that late game (even mid game) the physical attackers will start outdamaging him, and even the white mages with their summons while not having their white magic spells, Vivi is just rendered as an obsolete party member, despite how awesome he is.
[Badass Adorable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassAdorable): He's incredibly cute, but he has all the power a Black Mage needs to crush enemies.
[Beware the Nice Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BewareTheNiceOnes): Innocent, shy, and more than a little bit naive...and entirely capable of incinerating you with a thought.
[Big Brother Worship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBrotherWorship): For his part in his close friendship to Zidane, it's clear Vivi thinks highly of him.

[Black Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMage): Quintessential example in looks and skills, much less in character; to put it lightly, he's not aggressive in the slightest, and has to be put under serious threat to even think of using his powers at first.
[Blue Is Heroic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlueIsHeroic): Vivi is wearing a blue robe and is one of the good guys.
[Break the Cutie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakTheCutie): Figuring out his origins as a Black Mage really did a number on the poor kid.

[Breakout Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakoutCharacter): By far and away the most iconic character to come out of *IX*, and one of the most famous *Final Fantasy* characters outright, even rivaling the likes of [Gilgamesh](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyV), [Kefka](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVI), [Cloud](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVII), [Yuna](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyX), and [Balthier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXII) in popularity. He's appeared in *[Kingdom Hearts](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/KingdomHearts)* as the only representative from *IX* despite [Tetsuya Nomura](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/TetsuyaNomura)'s reluctance to use characters not designed by him, is a starting character in *[Dissidia Final Fantasy: Opera Omnia](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/DissidiaFinalFantasyOperaOmnia)*, and has made appearances without [Zidane](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHero) in games like *[World of Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/WorldOfFinalFantasy)* and *[Chocobo GP](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/ChocoboRacing)*.
[Charged Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChargedAttack): Can use Focus to power up a spell to use in his next turn.

[Child Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChildMage): Is about nine years old — physically, anyway. Chronologically, he's *six months old* at the start of the game, making him the youngest ever playable character in any *Final Fantasy* game.
[Colony Drop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColonyDrop): Meteor is just that; dropping a meteor on enemies.

[Cutscene Power to the Max](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CutscenePowerToTheMax): When a Black Waltz gets murdered, Vivi lets off a fire spell *much* bigger than he has access to at that point in the game (though it's actually a much realistic take on the trope as Vivi is shown passing out from exhaustion afterwards: his body is not ready to cast a spell this powerful yet, he only managed to do it because of the aforementioned murder). [This happens just after the battle with said button-pusher](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStoryIntegration), in which he starts in [Trance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperMode). This makes the battle *very easy*.

[Dark Is Not Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkIsNotEvil): He's a Black Mage but he's a very nice and gentle person. It causes problems throughout the game when people can't tell him apart from the hostile and destructive Black Mages the villains employ.
[Deadly Distant Finale](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadlyDistantFinale): As expected of his shortened lifespan, Vivi dies some time in between the final battle and when Zidane returns to Alexandria.

[Died Happily Ever After](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiedHappilyEverAfter): While intended as a major tear jerker, Vivi being granted life in Heaven for all of the heroics he has done is heartwarming in context.
QUOTE  "Everyone...Thank you. Farewell. My memories will be part of the sky."
[The Eeyore](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEeyore): Vivi is going through an existential crisis for the majority of the game, which leads him to be very morose and prone to worry.
[The Faceless](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFaceless): A play on the Black Mage usually having a face shadowed by the hat; in this title, that shadow *is* their face.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): Thanks to the actions of the Alexandrian Black Mages, Vivi finds himself on the receiving end of this quite frequently and is occasionally viewed as little more than a soulless golem.
[Gender-Blender Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenderBlenderName): In most countries, Vivi is a girl name.
[Happily Adopted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappilyAdopted): Raised by Quan and has fond memories of it. Quan was actually grooming Vivi to be a snack (something that Vivi isn't aware of).
[Inconsistent Spelling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling): His last name, Ornitier, is variably spelled "Orunitia", an exact romanization of the Japanese name.
[Innocent Prodigy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InnocentProdigy): He's very proficient with magic, but is also naive and innocent.
[Kid-Appeal Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KidAppealCharacter): His youth, cute design, and magical prowess.

[Killed Offscreen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffscreen): He dies some time between defeating Necron and the reunion in Alexandria at the very end (due to his very short lifespan), but his numerous "children" are present in his place, and it's clear [his soul has ascended into Heaven](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiedHappilyEverAfter).
[The Klutz](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheKlutz): Falls flat on his face the first time we see him (and several times later, of course).

[Linear Warriors, Quadratic Wizards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LinearWarriorsQuadraticWizards): Not so much in level progression, but the Focus skill means he can reach [extremely](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThereIsNoKillLikeOverkill) high damage even with beginner spells.
[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName) Vivi is latin for "Living" or "To Live", something his character is focused around.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): Vivi bears a strong resemblance to the Black Mage in the first *Final Fantasy* game. His pants are derived from the design of the Black Wizard/Magus (the upgrade of a Black Mage) of *Final Fantasy III*.

[Parental Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalSubstitute): Vivi's adoption by Master Quan leads the Qu to become a surrogate grandfather to him. Quan teaches Vivi about how the world works, and Vivi in turn refers to him as his "Grandpa."

[Parting-Words Regret](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PartingWordsRegret): Inverted; Vivi is delivering the narration at the ending because he has finally expired. It's implied that he didn't live long enough to see Zidane come back.

[Perpetual Frowner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PerpetualFrowner): He doesn't really have a face to express himself with, but it's implied.
QUOTE **Eiko:** Why the long face?! 
**Vivi:** Oh, my face is always like this.

[Phlebotinum Rebel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PhlebotinumRebel): Born as the prototype of a series of heartless, mindless slaughter machines, and goes on to fight against his creators and enslavers, becoming a hero in the process.
[Pintsized Powerhouse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PintsizedPowerhouse): No taller than your average kid, but holy hell does he pack a wallop with his spells.

[Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire): His very first spell is "Fire", and he uses it quite often outside of battle — for trying to scare off Alexandrian Guards, frying Black Waltz 3 to a crisp, for melting ice walls, [for cooking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MundaneUtility)...
[Posthumous Narration](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PosthumousNarration): Vivi is the one delivering [the closing narration](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EpilogueLetter) of the game from the afterlife.

[Power Gives You Wings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerGivesYouWings): Downplayed; While he doesn't gain literal wings, his Trance form grants him an angel wing crest over his chest, calling forward to the Black Waltz line.

[Punny Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunnyName): His name in Japanese is written as "Bibi". "Bibiru" roughly means "to be frightened", which describes Vivi's nervousness in combat, particularly early in the game.
[Running Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RunningGag): Vivi's either tripping or being bumped by someone either from the front or behind, notably by Puck.

[Shadowed Face, Glowing Eyes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShadowedFaceGlowingEyes): Vivi is a famous example of this. His design of small glowing eyes and an unknowable face shadowed by his hat are in direct homage to the classic Black Mage design.
[Shrinking Violet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShrinkingViolet): Tremendously shy and withdrawn, it's hard for him to connect with others.

[The Smart Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSmartGuy): He might not be very experienced, but Vivi is surprisingly knowledgeable and eloquent for his age; Quan taught him much over the course of his education.

[Spanner in the Works](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpannerInTheWorks): Despite all the mess that was finding out Garnet wanted to be kidnapped during the play and how she basically inserted herself into said play by accident and managed to fool everyone she was acting (while still wearing the White Mage robes to cover her face), in comes Vivi being chased by guards and sets Garnet's robes on fire by accident. Cue [Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap) by everyone as hell breaks loose and they are forced to crash land into Evil Forest instead of reaching Lindblum directly...
[Squishy Wizard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SquishyWizard): His spells can decimate enemies, but he has pitiful HP and defenses.
[Super Prototype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperPrototype): He's the first Black Mage, which is why he's so much stronger than them and has a longer life span.
[Unstoppable Rage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnstoppableRage): His response to Black Waltz 3 obliterating a group of Black Mages is to trance and obliterate Black Waltz 3.

[We All Die Someday](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeAllDieSomeday): He says this almost word-for-word (aside from using "stop" as a [Deadly Euphemism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadlyEuphemism)) against the [Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss) if you arrange your party so that he gets the [Pre Ass Kicking One Liner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PreAssKickingOneLiner).
QUOTE We're all gonna stop some day, but not today! Let's go, guys!

[Wise Beyond Their Years](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WiseBeyondTheirYears): His official age is 9 years old though we find out later he is much younger, and learns through the course of the game that he was created to be a killing machine AND that, because of this, he has a very short lifespan. Afterwards, he manages to take this sort of revelation better than most adults such as Kuja who is eventually told similar information about himself and responds to it by throwing a [Suicidal Cosmic Temper Tantrum](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuicidalCosmicTemperTantrum).

[Younger Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YoungerThanTheyLook): The game guide lists his age as 9, which is about what most people assume. In truth he is no more than 6 months old when he buys his ticket to see *I Want to Be Your Canary* and the game begins. He only lived with his "Grandpa" for about four months before Quan died.
[Amazon Brigade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmazonBrigade): Inversion. In Alexandria, an all-female army is the norm, and he's the captain of the small all-male unit.

[Attack! Attack! Attack!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AttackAttackAttack): As the person with the highest attack stat (next to Zidane with the right equipment) and whose trance *triples* his damage output, this is a pretty good strategy with him.

[Badass Normal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassNormal): He uses no magic naturally and travels in a group where almost every other member can use a supernaturally based fighting style in some form. When his [Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak) activates, instead of gaining new powers, he simply hits three times harder than normal.
[Battle Couple](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleCouple): With Beatrix in Disc 3. Due to love letter shenanigans, they are a couple that kicks much ass together.
[Belligerent Sexual Tension](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BelligerentSexualTension): He and Beatrix ultimately ended up together despite their initially antagonistic relationship.
[BFS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS): His swords get pretty damn big later on in the game.

[The Big Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBigGuy): The hardest-hitting member of the party in pure power, and wielder of large swords. He views his role within the party as "Garnet's protector" and wears the heaviest armor as part of this.

[Black-and-White Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackAndWhiteMorality): His worldview is all about this, especially before character development kicks in.
QUOTE **Steiner:** I am just trying to do what is right! 
**Morrid:** Who decides right or wrong? You? 
**Steiner:** Anyone can tell right from wrong. 
**Morrid:** Ha ha ha...Still as green as a pickle.

[Boyfriend-Blocking Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BoyfriendBlockingDad): Even though he's not actually Garnet's father, he still acts like the comedic version of this trope in regards to her. He even hates the bad boy she's fallen for.
[Butt-Monkey](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButtMonkey): Often the butt of Zidane's mischief.
[The Captain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCaptain): Leader of the Knights of Pluto.
[Cast from Hit Points](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastFromHitPoints): Steiner has Darkside, which depletes 12.5% of his max HP in order to attack.

[Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment): Out of the eight playable characters, Steiner is the one who is most changed by his experiences in the game, learning to grow out of his [Black-and-White Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackAndWhiteMorality) outlook and to think for himself instead of blindly following orders.

[The Chew Toy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChewToy): The game punishes him *a lot*, but most of it is pre-[Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment). After he starts to wise up about the world, [he gets a few bones thrown his way](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThrowTheDogABone).

[The Comically Serious](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheComicallySerious): His self-seriousness is played for laughs, such as when he's looking concerned at the Princess Garnet Doll or generally being unapproachable to villagers who could redirect him.

[Conflicting Loyalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ConflictingLoyalty): The basis of his [Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment) is what he should be loyal to: The mad queen, the heroic princess, or Alexandria itself?  (SPOILER) He ends up choosing the princess and Alexandria as a secondary loyalty through her, as he realizes that Queen Brahne is too far gone and the country would be safer under Garnet.
[Cool Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolSword): Uses Knightly longswords which vary from standard sizes to the [BFS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS).

[Dark and Troubled Past](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkAndTroubledPast): Orphaned at the age of four during the last war between Alexandria and Burmecia. It's also implied that [he's seen a lot of war and strife in his time](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShellShockedVeteran), as he tells Garnet that he doesn't want her to experience war "as I have".
[Desperation Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DesperationAttack): Minus Strike deals damage equivalent to the difference between Steiner's current and max HP.

[Dumb Muscle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DumbMuscle): Played with. He comes off as an oaf at first, but it's more out of obstinacy than any actual idiocy; he's mainly lacking in [Street Smarts](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StreetSmart) and worldly experience, and is surprisingly well-read and verbose for a man of his position. [Yoshitaka Amano](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/YoshitakaAmano)'s original designs show that he's a pretty muscular guy. Keep in mind that [he's strong enough to run around in that heavy armor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Determinator) (even running ahead of Zidane while carrying Garnet out of Evil Forest) and only be winded at one point early on in the game (after running up an entire tower's worth of stairs).

[Empowered Badass Normal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EmpoweredBadassNormal): He has absolutely no magic of his own, but he and Vivi work out a combat skill in which Vivi can enchant Steiner's sword with one of his spells.

[Excalibur](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Excalibur): One of his swords is called the Excalibur, but it is unknown if it has a connection to King Arthur. Players who manage to get to the end of the game fast enough can secure him a sword called Excalibur II.

[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): Confirmed by  invoked  [Word of God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WordOfGod) to be modeled on [Inspector Zenigata](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Manga/LupinTheThird). He shares some of the latter's features (square jaw, prominent eyelashes) and core personality traits (authority figure who rivals a monkey-like thief).

[Fire-Forged Friends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FireForgedFriends): He initially treats Zidane with incredible hatred for kidnapping the princess (ignoring that she herself wanted that). As he realizes that Zidane and Tantalus only want to keep Garnet safe just like he does, Steiner gradually warms to Zidane enough to openly root for he and Garnet to be together.

[Gratuitous Latin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GratuitousLatin): In the Italian translation, not only has him spouting Latin idioms here and there, but his techniques are renamed in Latin (as Gladius, for Sword Attacks, and Magicum for magic sword attacks).

[Heavy Equipment Class](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeavyEquipmentClass): One of the two permanent party members capable of using heavy armour, along with being the only character able to use knight swords.

[Honor Before Reason](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HonorBeforeReason): He refuses to travel with thieves until ordered to by Garnet (despite the dangers of traveling alone), and he refuses to believe Brahne has turned evil until after even Beatrix has accepted it.
[I Gave My Word](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IGaveMyWord): His oath of fealty is the source of his inner conflict after Brahne turns evil.

[Ineffectual Sympathetic Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IneffectualSympatheticVillain): It's a [Hero Antagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroAntagonist) thing in this case. At first he is the lawful soldier hunting a band of thieves and kidnappers, but he's working for the villain.

[Informed Attribute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InformedAttribute): Everyone mocking his rusty armor is a [Running Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RunningGag) throughout the game, but there is no rust showing on his character model or in any FMVs.
[In-Series Nickname](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InSeriesNickname): Zidane refers to him as "Rusty."

[Inspector Javert](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InspectorJavert): He makes no qualms about wanting to arrest Zidane and the rest of the Tantalus because of what they did. However, Steiner noticeably relaxes this stance once they prove invaluable allies.

[Intergenerational Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IntergenerationalFriendship): With Vivi: despite an age gap of more than two decades, Steiner has great respect for Vivi's magical abilities, and is openly kind and respectful to him, in sharp contrast with [how he treats Zidane and the rest of Tantalus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassToOne).
[Jerkass to One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassToOne): He's really only a prick to Zidane, as he's very respectful to Vivi and Garnet, and doesn't interact much with the rest of the party.

[Knight in Shining Armor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightInShiningArmor): Does his best to be this but is often more of a [Knight Templar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightTemplar) of the [Lawful Stupid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LawfulStupid) variety before his [Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment) kicks in. At that point, he's all about the heroic saving the day stuff.

[The Lancer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLancer): To Zidane for the first half of the game. While Zidane is mature, laid back, and open-minded, Steiner is loud, duty-driven, and naive. Their relationships with Vivi and Garnet also contrasts, with Zidane being Vivi's [Big Brother Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBrotherMentor) and flirting with Garnet while Steiner treats Vivi as his superior and Garnet as his charge. Ultimately, they both wish to protect Garnet, even if they have different ideas on how to do it, and of the first four party members, Steiner is easily the most capable after Zidane, both in-battle and when it comes to thinking on his feet.

[Last-Name Basis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastNameBasis): He's the only character in the entire *Final Fantasy* series that the player's [name choice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HelloInsertNameHere) affects the surname. It's also done in-universe, as Brahne needs a moment to remember his name when she orders him and Beatrix to find Garnet at the very start of the game.

[Lawful Stupid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LawfulStupid): Steiner believes in [Black-and-White Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackAndWhiteMorality), so he took any instance to thumb his nose upon any member of Tantalus (especially Zidane), and he remains [bullheadedly determined](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Determinator) to return Garnet to Alexandria despite the fact that this is not only against her wishes, but against overwhelming evidence that Queen Brahne has turned evil. However, it should be noted that during said time, *nobody* was 100% sure that Alexandria was behind everything. Most of his [Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment) revolves around him getting over this.

[Let's Get Dangerous!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LetsGetDangerous): He's generally depicted as a buffoon early on in the game, but when he gets into a real fight, he's a pretty good swordsman. Story-wise, this happens when he teams up with Beatrix in Disc 3. Fighting to protect the kingdom at her side causes him to automatically to enter into Trance. Notably, he also does his job very well in defending Dagger during their trek through the Mist to South Gate in Disc 2.

[Magikarp Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagikarpPower): His Sword Arts ability. With the exception of Minus Strike (which requires the player to [keep him at low HP](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ViolationOfCommonSense)), all of them are pretty much a waste of time as he will deal more damage by just [attacking every round](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AttackAttackAttack). But his lategame weapons give him access to abilities like Climhazzard and Shock - both of which are very well worth the time.

[Mighty Glacier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MightyGlacier): He's slow in both mind and body, but his swords hit very hard, having the game's highest Strength. His Trance mode also triples his attack power.
[My Country, Right or Wrong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyCountryRightOrWrong): Eventually realizes he can still act on duty if he changes that duty to following the Princess' orders, not the Queen's.

[No Social Skills](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoSocialSkills):Before the game's events, Steiner didn't need to come out of his shell or learn the social skills used outside the castle.
QUOTE **Steiner:** I humbly request your assistance to get back to the castle.

QUOTE **Female Red Mage:** Ha-ha-ha! That's a new one!

[O.O.C. Is Serious Business](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OOCIsSeriousBusiness): He was such a vocal critic of Zidane for most of the first half of the game that it comes as a surprise to everyone that Steiner entrusted Garnet's safety to him, because Steiner plans to stay behind and help Beatrix and Freya.

[Overrated and Underleveled](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OverratedAndUnderleveled): He is the captain of the Knights of Pluto, has implied to have had war experience, and can rough up the heroes. Yet by the time he joins, he is at level one and [due to being removed from the party for awhile, lags behind everyone but Freya](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CantCatchUp). It's somewhat justified in that the Knights of Pluto are seen as incompetent boobs. It's suggested in side material that Steiner in his youth was one of the strongest knights of the kingdom and Beatrix's equal but a combination of becoming a stickler for the rules as he got older and having to deal with the incompetence of his division has seriously dulled his skills and kept him from progressing as Beatrix did until he starts getting over his negative personality traits later in the game.

[Papa Wolf](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PapaWolf): Used comically in regards to Garnet in the first two discs in regards to the "danger" that Zidane supposedly posses to her. It's played much more seriously in Disc 3 when he teams up with Beatrix to protect her.

[Parental Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalSubstitute): Alongside Beatrix after Brahne passes on, as he assumes the role of the stern [Boyfriend-Blocking Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BoyfriendBlockingDad) to Garnet.
[Perpetual Frowner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PerpetualFrowner): He's never happy; more of a "stoic duty" kind of guy. This can be seen in his render and his in-game model is the same.

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog):
    - We know he's not such a total jerk when he treats Vivi nicely, even calling him "Master". It's the only time we see Steiner treat anyone aside from royalty with any respect for most of the first half of the game. - While he boasted to Zidane that he'd be hanged for kidnapping Garnet, once he's out of earshot Steiner concedes that Zidane saved Garnet's life several times by then. Steiner then decides he'd petition the queen for a reduced sentence; Life in prison as opposed to execution. - He's also disgusted by Black Waltz 3's callous slaughter of the black mages and rushes after Vivi to help him fight the villain without hesitation. - It's worth noting that Steiner's trust and respect for Vivi is so high that (SPOILER) Vivi being the one to tell him that Queen Brahne ordered the execution of Princess Garnet was what finally got him to seriously question his blind loyalty to the queen.
[The Rival](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRival): He sees Beatrix as one because she's also an officer in Alexandria's military. It's mutual.
[Shell-Shocked Veteran](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShellShockedVeteran): Implies this to Garnet, when he tells her she must never experience war "as I have."
[Spell Blade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpellBlade): When he is in a party with Vivi, they can team up so Steiner can use the deadly Sword Magic skills.

[Throw the Dog a Bone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThrowTheDogABone): After he hooks up with Beatrix late in the game, he stops being such a [Butt-Monkey](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButtMonkey) and becomes far more competent.

[To Be Lawful or Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ToBeLawfulOrGood): The crux of his [Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment) is this dilemma. The lawful decision is obeying his queen and arresting the thieves and kidnappers he's working with, but the good decision is helping a band of brave and friendly rogues stop his power-mad queen. He realizes that he can be both lawful *and* good by obeying the heroic princess.

[Token Human](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenHuman): Everyone else is either visibly not human (Freya, Vivi, Quina), [Ambiguously Human](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguouslyHuman) (Amarant), a human subspecies (Garnet, Eiko), or a Genome (Zidane). Steiner is the only explicit human among them.

[Trademark Favorite Food](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrademarkFavoriteFood): During his time in Lindblum, he develops a taste for Gysahl Pickles, a local food implied to have a very strong flavor and terrible smell. He later exploits the smell to smuggle Garnet past a checkpoint in a large sack full of them.
[Undying Loyalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndyingLoyalty): Alexandria can count on his sword no matter what; Princess and later, Queen, Garnet could not ask for a more loyal guard.

[The Unfavorite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfavorite): The Knights of Pluto are generally mocked in Alexandria for being a bunch of incompetent boobs, fit only for an easy job like protecting the Princess. Queen Brahne even forgets Steiner's name because she thinks so little of him.

tropeName: Why Did It Have to Be Snakes?
tropeNotes: [Why Did It Have to Be Snakes?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhyDidItHaveToBeSnakes): His first reaction to seeing an oglop is to kick it away. Even when said oglop is, unbeknownst to him, a transformed Regent Cid.

[Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionGirl): Despite her nickname, Garnet is more of [The Red Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRedMage), being able to use summon magic to kick some butt while also healing others.

[Adopted into Royalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdoptedIntoRoyalty): To replace the King and Queen’s biological daughter who died as a toddler. She originally had no idea there was a Princess Garnet before her.
[Anger Born of Worry](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AngerBornOfWorry): Happens in the ending where Zidane returns in dramatic fashion. She hugs him, then beats on his chest in anger, and then cries on it.

[Badass Bookworm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBookworm): Knows a lot since she couldn't do much more in the castle other than study the books in Alexandria Castle's library, and she puts it to good use throughout the adventure. This is especially apparent when her familiarity with "I Wanna Be Your Canary" enables her to perform on the fly with impeccable skill.
[Battle Couple](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleCouple): She and Zidane become a couple in time for the end-game of their quest to save the world..

[Big Sister Instinct](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigSisterInstinct): Usually to Vivi in earlier Disc 1, most notably when comforting him in the Cargo Ship after Black Waltz No. 3 massacred other black mages, and in Disc 2, especially in Black Mage Village when she expresses concern at Vivi's confusion to other black mages' existence. Less so, and usually inverted, to [Eiko](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenkiGirl) as the latter tends to play the 'big sis' part despite being *[ten years younger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdorablyPrecociousChild)*.

[Blessed with Suck](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlessedWithSuck): Garnet's summoning powers were a serious liability in Disc 1 and part of Disc 2; not only did they result in Garnet being chased from one end of the Mist Continent to the other by Brahne's lackeys and almost being killed when her eidolons were forcibly removed, but the MP costs were so high that she couldn't even use them.

[Break the Cutie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakTheCutie): The conflict with her mother, watching the destruction caused by her nation, and ultimately the destruction of her own queendom have all caused her so much trauma she turned mute for a while.
[Cassandra Truth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CassandraTruth): She'd spotted Kuja and suspected him of influencing Brahne's descent into madness well before the game's events, but nobody believed her.

[Coy, Girlish Flirt Pose](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoyGirlishFlirtPose): This is her victory pose if she's equipped with a rod. She spins the rod around and holds it behind her back while crossing one leg in front of the other, tilting her neck and smiling slightly.

[Death from Above](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathFromAbove): When in Trance, her eidolons remain behind her ready to attack again and again, no summon needed. So if she isn't used and her Trance meter stays up, expect lots of attacks.

[Deliberately Distressed Damsel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeliberatelyDistressedDamsel): Attempts to invoke this in order to escape Alexandria by asking to be kidnapped. Unbeknownst to her, Tantalus was there to kidnap her anyway.

[Establishing Character Moment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EstablishingCharacterMoment):
    - At the very start of the game, when cornered, [she looks Zidane in the eye, smiles, and jumps off the tower (holding onto a rope) to get away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PluckyGirl). Then, when he catches up, she turns things around and *[asks to be kidnapped](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeliberatelyDistressedDamsel)*. - Another important one is when she and Zidane are being chased by Steiner after she's asked to be kidnapped, all three find themselves on stage *during the play and forced to improvise*. Garnet doesn't even flinch and merely throws herself into the part, *despite the fact that she's never performed in a play before, [only read the exact performance many times in a book](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBookworm)*. This establishes early on that Garnet may lack experience in a lot of things, but she's VERY quick to adapt.

[Expository Hairstyle Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExpositoryHairstyleChange): The hair from her [Important Haircut](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImportantHaircut) has grown back to its original length by the end of the game. This is both to show that time has passed and that she has grown into her new role as [The High Queen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHighQueen).
[Form-Fitting Wardrobe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FormFittingWardrobe): Her orange jumpsuit that she wears for much of the game.

[Friend to Bugs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendToBugs): [To oglops, at least](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DownplayedTrope). She gently picks one up in Dali without any revulsion, and only pretends to freak out *after* someone points out that most girls hate bugs. It [helped](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustifiedTrope) that she has never seen one before and looks at it more with curiosity about something she never knew before leaving the castle.

[Gameplay and Story Integration](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStoryIntegration):
    - When confronted by Ramuh, she admits that she was afraid of the eidolons inside her. The reason the MP costs to summon them are so high is probably due to a mental block on her part. When she suffers her [Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD), she has a chance of freezing up in combat and not being able to do anything. It's also at this time that she's able to start relearning her summon spells and re-establishing her bond with them, which probably helps her cope with her pain note  The player *can* get Garnet to summon eidolons early in the game. If they use a cheat to boost her MP or simply through consistent levelling, her MP will be high enough to summon them. Though, given that the lowest MP cost for an eidolon (Shiva) is 94 at that point, you're better off waiting . - Similarly, all of her eidolons (most of whom are series staples that have been around since *[Final Fantasy III](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIII)*), when used in cutscenes, *actually* work as they do in battle. It's taken a step further when she seeks out an eidolon that will save her mother's naval fleet, only to find... Leviathan. The tidal-wave-summoning sea creature that would logically only serve to *destroy* a naval fleet.

[Gameplay and Story Segregation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation): After Zidane states that they can't keep on calling her Garnet so as to not get caught, you get the option of renaming her. Canonically, she goes by Dagger, but there's nothing preventing you from naming her Garnet, which everyone accepts as if it were any different name.
[Girly Run](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GirlyRun): More like girly *prance*, which she does while holding her hands out to the side.

[The Glomp](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGlomp): It sees usage during the [Grand Finale](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrandFinale) when Garnet *dives* on Zidane. It's a [Call-Back](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CallBack) to Zidane's Glomp Fail at the end of the Conde Petie wedding.

[Guilt Complex](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuiltComplex): Garnet's [Fatal Flaw](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FatalFlaw): she has a bad habit of blaming herself for a lot of the destruction and suffering that occurs throughout the game, even when no sane assessment of it would hold her responsible. This is especially apparent after Alexandria is destroyed and she falls into a [Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD). Her [Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment) is centered around moving past this, with her symbolically shedding her guilt and sorrow in Disc 3 with an [Important Haircut](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImportantHaircut).
[Happily Adopted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappilyAdopted): Until Brahne turned evil she had a good relationship with her. However, she had no idea she was adopted until well into the game.

[Head-Turning Beauty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeadTurningBeauty): Garnet is well-known for her beauty, with several characters remarking on it and Baku even calling her the most beautiful woman in Alexandria.

[The Heart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeart): She believes in diplomacy and working together, and initially she's the only girl in the group. At first, she's afraid to use her [political connections and charisma](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFace), but they're [what eventually unite the entire Mist Continent against Kuja](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenghisGambit).
[Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD): After Alexandria's destruction. It's so severe that it renders her completely mute, and even interferes with her ability to use magic in battle.
[High-Class Gloves](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HighClassGloves): Garnet wears a matching pair with her princess dress.
[The High Queen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHighQueen): Following Brahne's death she becomes the queen of Alexandria and is quite popular with her subjects.

[Hope Spot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HopeSpot): During the battle between Brahne's fleet and Kuja at the Iifa Tree, Garnet races to find the eidolon that Eiko told her about in order to save her mother. Unfortunately, that eidolon turns out to be Leviathan, whose signature attack, creating large tidal waves, would only serve to destroy the fleet.

[Horned Humanoid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HornedHumanoid): Like all summoners, she had one. It was removed to make her identical to the real Princess Garnet. This means she cannot speak directly to the Eidolons as Eiko did as that requires a horn, although she is able to still communicate her intentions regardless.

[Identical Stranger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IdenticalStranger): The reason she was adopted into the Alexandria royal family was because of how she strongly resembles the real Princess Garnet who died.

[I Have Many Names](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IHaveManyNames): Goes by the nickname Dagger in an effort to keep a low profile. Her *real* name, as in the one she had before she was adopted into the Alexandria Royal Family, is Sarah.

[Important Haircut](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImportantHaircut): After finally coming to terms with her grief, she cuts her hair to above shoulder-length, symbolically casting off her sorrow in the process.

[Improbable Weapon User](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobableWeaponUser): She favors [rods](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicWand), fittingly for [The Medic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMedic). She can use rackets too.
[It's All My Fault](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsAllMyFault): She blames herself for a lot of the destruction and suffering that occurs, even when no sane assessment of it would hold her responsible.
[Last of His Kind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastOfHisKind): She and Eiko are the only summoners left. Eiko was thrilled to find out she wasn't alone anymore.

[Mad Scientist's Beautiful Daughter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadScientistsBeautifulDaughter): Vicious Queen's Beautiful Daughter's in this case. She's adopted, but otherwise in keeping with the trope. She works against her parent and falls for the hero.

[Male Gaze](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MaleGaze): Her character model not only has a finely sculpted and pronounced butt, but the textures actually have "light" reflecting off her outfit in that spot. Coupled with most battle scenes and animations putting the camera behind the party, players will find their eyes drawn to her derriere by design. This becomes even more apparent after she cuts her hair, getting rid of the main obstruction between her backside and the camera.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Twice over, with both her royal name and her birth name.
    - Garnet is the birth stone for January. [Garnet's birthday is January 15](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual). - Sarah means "princess" (lit. woman of high rank) in Hebrew.

[Ms. Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MsFanservice): Despite her outfit being much more conservative than usual holders of this title in the series, the jumpsuit still emphasizes her hips, rear and groin, and her Trance form is straight [Stripperiffic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Stripperiffic).

[Mystical Waif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MysticalWaif): She's not quite as mysterious as other examples, being that she lived in Alexandria as the princess all her life, but she fulfills the narrative purpose of starting the plot and possessing supernatural powers.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): Though as a princess she would go on to be named 'Garnet', her birth name is 'Sarah', a subtle reference to Princess Sarah, a character who appears in *[Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyI)* and was subsequently referenced with another princess of the same name in *[Final Fantasy III](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIII)*.
[Oblivious Adoption](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObliviousAdoption): She had no idea she was adopted until a long time afterward.

[Painted-On Pants](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PaintedOnPants): Her outfit not only shows her general princess butt shape but seemingly rides up so high one has to wonder not only how she doesn't feel it between her glutes but if it can leave any rashes.
[Pimped-Out Dress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PimpedOutDress): A grand, white dress that she wears whenever conducting princessly duties.

[Plucky Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PluckyGirl): A variant in that a lot of her pain is self-inflicted, and a large part of her character growth is realizing that not everything is her fault and she shouldn't put so much pressure on herself.

[Power Up Letdown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerUpLetdown): Her Trance is completely useless for the first half of the game. It powers up her summons, but she doesn't have any MP to call them yet (unless the player does an insane amount of level grinding).
[Rebellious Princess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RebelliousPrincess): Plotting your own kidnapping as part of a political maneuver against your mother the queen is certainly rebellious.

[The Red Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRedMage): After regaining her summons and getting Eiko, she shifts more to this archetype than a traditional [White Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage), including the [Master of None](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterOfNone) connotations — being neither as efficient at magical damage as Vivi nor at healing as Eiko. With a racket equipped, she's also a decent physical attacker to boot, although nowhere near as good as Zidane, Freya, Amarant, or Steiner.
[Replacement Goldfish](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReplacementGoldfish): For the original Princess, who died as an infant.

[Royals Who Actually Do Something](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalsWhoActuallyDoSomething): Deconstructed. Due to her taking her duties as a royal very seriously, Garnet wants to be this trope, but she has an unfortunate tendency to be responsible to a fault and try to do everything herself instead of relying on others: most notably, her choice to leave the party and travel back to Alexandria to try to reason with Brahne gets her captured and her eidolons extracted, forcing Zidane and the party to rescue her and giving Brahne a set of tools to wreak destruction on the Mist Continent with. In addition, her [Guilt Complex](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuiltComplex) causes her to be *deeply* hard on herself for the mistakes she makes, and even things that were outside of her control, causing her to have a [Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD) in Disc 3 following Alexandria's destruction. Fortunately, her [Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment) allows her to move past her guilt and blossom into a proper version of this trope, being a front-line fighter against Kuja in Disc 4, and the epilogue shows her having become [The High Queen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHighQueen).
[Samaritan Syndrome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SamaritanSyndrome): Once again, she puts far more pressure and blame on herself than anyone would reasonably expect her to.

[Sci-Fi Bob Haircut](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SciFiBobHaircut): Post-[Important Haircut](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImportantHaircut). While the game is heavily [Medieval Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MedievalFantasy), it still has prominent [Steampunk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Steampunk) elements.

[She Cleans Up Nicely](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SheCleansUpNicely): Downplayed: Garnet is a famous beauty even when she's wearing her normal travelling outfit, but when she dresses up in a [Pimped-Out Dress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PimpedOutDress) for her coronation as queen, the party is collectively enraptured by her, and Zidane in particular is rendered completely speechless.
[The Smart Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSmartGirl): She has all the benefits of a royal education, including knowledge about many of the locales the party visits.

[Sole Survivor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoleSurvivor): Garnet is the only remaining survivor of Garland's attack on Madain Sari, as the others, Eiko's parents and grandfather, all passed away within five years.

[Stay in the Kitchen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StayInTheKitchen): She takes Zidane's refusal to let her join the scout party to Burmecia as this and is offended by it, causing her to leave the party in Lindblum (after drugging them) and trying to solve the problem on her own by talking to Brahne.

[Stripperific](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Stripperific): Her [Trance form](http://www.duose.com/p/2003/0730/4378_5608800000.gif)◊ essentially turns her outfit into a one-piece swimsuit that shows off her cleavage and behind.
[Summon Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SummonMagic): She has more summons than Eiko, but doesn't get to use them for a while.
[They Call Him "Sword"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheyCallHimSword): She chooses the name "Dagger" for herself when Zidane tells her they can't go around calling her "Garnet" everywhere.

[Took a Level in Cheerfulness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInCheerfulness): For about half the game, especially after some of the more tragic events, she's pretty dour and is rarely shown with a smile. After she deals with her grief, she sheds most of her worries and becomes more upbeat and determined.

[Tsundere](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Tsundere): Initially, she's too naive to pick up on Zidane's flirting, but she becomes a Type B when she wises up about it, generally being pleasant towards him but both shooting him down when he hits on her and getting snippy when he hits on other girls. Even when they reunite at the end of the game, her response to seeing him again is to [hurl herself onto him](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGlomp) and then [pound him in the chest.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AngerBornOfWorry)

[The Ugly Guy's Hot Daughter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUglyGuysHotDaughter): Ugly Queen's Hot Daughter in this case. It may appear to be justified, as they aren't blood-related...except Garnet was specifically adopted due to being identical to the Queen's deceased daughter.
[Uptown Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UptownGirl): She is a princess (later queen) and Zidane a thief.

[When She Smiles](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhenSheSmiles): She hardly smiles at all due to her being serious and worried all the time. When she finally overcomes her sorrows and doubts, she [cuts her hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImportantHaircut) and gives a genuine smile.

[White Magician Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMagicianGirl): She fits the archetype with its focus on compassion and healing others and starts set as a [White Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage), before she can use her summon magic. After that, she falls more under [Red Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedMage). She even wears a [White Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage) hood early in the game.
[You Are in Command Now](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreInCommandNow):  (SPOILER) Queen Brahme's death at the end of Disc 2 results in Garnet having to take the throne.

[Aborted Arc](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbortedArc): Her development and subplot with Fratley are largely dropped after Cleyra. While it does have a conclusion of sorts just prior to the end of the game, Freya herself expresses misgivings about both Burmecia's uncertain future and Fratley's affections, given his memory still hasn't properly returned.
[Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionGirl): Your second female party member, and one of your primary heavy-hitters.
[Animal Motifs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimalMotifs): Dragons feature in most of her attacks.
[Badass Longcoat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassLongcoat): A long and red tattered coat that has weathered her travels and fighting.
[Barefoot Cartoon Animal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarefootCartoonAnimal): She's a humanoid mouse with clawed hands and feet, as such shoes would probably be impractical for her.

[Break the Cutie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakTheCutie): First her kingdom is devastated. Then the man she loved and thought dead is alive but doesn't remember her. *Then* her kingdom's sister country Cleyra is destroyed. All this happens in short time one after the other.
[Bring My Red Jacket](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BringMyRedJacket): Bear in mind that Freya goes through the most *emotional* injury.
[Can't Catch Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CantCatchUp): Due to being out of the party for a good portion of the game, she (and Steiner) end up in the back of the pack in terms of levels.

[Characterization Marches On](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterizationMarchesOn): Her introductory cutscene has her speaking rather casually while jokingly telling Zidane that she's gonna kick his butt after he calls her rat face. She begins speaking more eloquently as the game progresses and acts a lot more stoic with nary a joke (granted, this is all due to [Burmecia and Cleyra getting destroyed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TraumaCongaLine) and [her inability to save those towns or her own people](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FailureKnight)).

[Cherry Blossoms](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CherryBlossoms): She has an attack called "Cherry Blossom". It hits all opponents for damage and scatters petals all over the place. It's pretty much hitting all of the above-cited meanings - Freya's deadliness, her search for her first love, and her maturation.

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): To Zidane, mainly.
QUOTE **Zidane:** "Let me get the final kill! I have a date on the line here!" 
**Freya:** "...You're ridiculous."

[Death from Above](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathFromAbove): When Freya goes into Trance, her Jump transforms into a barrage of spears cast from above, and she'll stay in the air until her gauge drops to zero. Essentially she gives free damage for several turns with no chance of being hurt.
[Demoted to Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemotedToExtra): Poor Freya's significance drops after the party leaves Cleyra mid-way through the second disc.
[Dragon Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DragonKnight): She is actually called this rather then Dragoon as the job-class is typically translated in Final Fantasy.
[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): To Freija in the Spanish and Italian translations, Freia in the German translation, and Freyja in the French translation.

[Enemy Mine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemyMine): Despite not forgiving Beatrix for her role in conquering Burmecia and Cleyra, Freya fights alongside her against the Bandersnatches as Zidane and Vivi escape with Dagger.
[The Faceless](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFaceless): Freya's face is mostly obscured by her hat. It can be seen in the ending FMV.
[Failure Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FailureKnight): She failed to protect her country, and then tried and failed again to save her entire race.
[Femme Fatalons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FemmeFatalons): Both her fingers and her nails are extremely long.
[Heartbroken Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeartbrokenBadass): This knight lost her true love long ago and is still looking for him by the time of her introduction.
[Heavy Equipment Class](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeavyEquipmentClass): The second of the two permanent party members capable of using heavy armour.
[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): During the scene at a Cleyra Cathedral, Freya is shown to be a pretty skilled dancer.
[In a Single Bound](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InASingleBound): Freya can jump high both in and out of combat.

[Javelin Thrower](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JavelinThrower): Rather then coming down on enemies in a divebomb as usual for dragoons when doing jump, Freya instead throws her spear at enemies like this from the air. In Trance this is turned up where she will stay in the air and use the *Spear* ability and stay safely in the air while raining javelins down on enemies.
[Lady of War](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyOfWar): She's calm, polite and dignified even when dealing with opponents and is an excellent warrior knight.
[Love Hurts](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoveHurts): She has been searching for one Sir Fratley for much of her life, and what happens when she finally found him? He doesn't even remember her.
[Lunacy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Lunacy): Her Luna spell inflicts Berserk everyone on the field, forcing them to only use the attack command until it's cured or it wears off.
[Magic Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicKnight): Her skillset is surprisingly magical for a Dragoon, complete with summoning magical cherry blossoms and spectral dragons.
[Mana Drain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManaDrain): Can steal enemy MP and restore the whole party's with White Draw.

[Maybe Ever After](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MaybeEverAfter): Although she and Sir Fratley are [together](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OfficialCouple) in her ending, she's seen expressing doubts as he still does not remember her. Notably, she doesn't return any of his affections physically or verbally.
[My Greatest Failure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGreatestFailure): Being too late to save Burmecia, her hometown.

[My Greatest Second Chance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGreatestSecondChance): Protecting Cleyra is her redemption for failing Burmecia. This does not work either, turning this entire arc into an impressive [Trauma Conga Line](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TraumaCongaLine) for Freya.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): [Reis'](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyTactics) [Wind,](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/TrialsOfMana) [Kain's Lance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIV).

[Random Effect Spell](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RandomEffectSpell): Six Dragons, with the very helpful description if highlighted after pressing Select of "[See for yourself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SchmuckBait)." It can do a myriad of things to the party, from healing everyone entirely, down to [reducing everyone's HP and/or MP to one](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HPToOne).

[Rat Woman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RatMen): Freya and her race are all [anthropomorphic rats](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RodentsOfUnusualSize). Interestingly, they don't get [the same treatment that giant rats get in other media](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouDirtyRat), and are portrayed as quite noble.
[Shaping Your Attacks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShapingYourAttacks): She can create spectral dragons for several of her attacks such as Dragon's Breath, Dragon Crest and Cherry Blossom.

[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): Reis' Wind is one for *[Trials of Mana](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/TrialsOfMana)*. In that game, the character Riesz (for whom ["Reis" was a valid translation of her name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange) before her official localization in 2019) wields a lance like Freya does, and her kingdom is associated with wind and dragons. She also loses said kingdom over the course of the game (like how Freya loses Burmecia and Cleyra). And to complete the circle, "Freya" is the name of one of Riesz' summon spells.
[Statuesque Stunner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatuesqueStunner): A little over 6'1 (187cm to be exact).
[Team Mom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeamMom): Has shades of this in her interactions with Vivi in particular.

[Throw the Dog a Bone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThrowTheDogABone): The first two discs are basically a big [Trauma Conga Line](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TraumaCongaLine) for her and she's later left [Out of Focus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutOfFocus). The ending implies that she and Sir Fratley are together again, although even that has an overall bitter tinge to it.

[Trauma Conga Line](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TraumaCongaLine): She loses her kingdom, the peaceful country Cleyra she was determined to protect after the refugees escaped from the invasion, and when she finally finds her love after being gone for so long, he doesn't remember her. Ouch.
[When She Smiles](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhenSheSmiles): In the ending FMV when Garnet and Zidane are reunited, her face can be seen in full and she's smiling happily.
[Acrofatic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Acrofatic): You wouldn't expect someone of Quina's girth to be able to jump around like that.
[Alliterative Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlliterativeName): With Qs no less.

[Ambiguous Gender](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguousGender): To such an extent that the narration of the game itself refers to Quina as "him" and "s/he". If game mechanics are counted, gender-specific equipment leans toward male; on the other hand, certain translations use female pronouns. The Lamia's "Entrance" ability, which does not work on female party members, works on Quina. Also, Zidane will not protect Quina when equipped with the "Protect Girls" ability. One of the Steam achievements pokes fun at this with the "Femme Fatales?" title and requires you to have an all female party plus Quina. note  If Quina were female, it would give you a [Gender-Equal Ensemble](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenderEqualEnsemble).
    - As of their appearance in Opera Omnia, Quina's pronouns have officially been changed to they/them.

[Beware the Silly Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BewareTheSillyOnes): Easily the biggest source of comic relief in the party, and is initially presented as being incompetent, but their Blue Magic is nothing to sneeze at.
[Big Eater](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigEater): When they're not currently eating, they're complaining about being hungry.
[Cannibalism Superpower](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CannibalismSuperpower): They learn spells for their Blue Magic via eating monsters.
