[Chef of Iron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChefOfIron): Cooks and eats monsters on the battlefield.
[Chekhov's Gunman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChekhovsGunman): Quina can be found in the Alexandria Castle's kitchens right at the beginning of the game when controlling Steiner.

[Cloud Cuckoo Lander](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CloudCuckooLander): Quina is...not all there, even at the *best* of times. For instance, they're very happy at [marrying Vivi](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItMakesSenseInContext).
QUOTE "I...so happy..."
[Cutscene Incompetence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CutsceneIncompetence): Quina is at first presented as hopelessly inept in catching frogs. Once the player takes over, that can change.

[Disc-One Nuke](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneNuke):
    - Frog Drop. Since it's a [Fixed Damage Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FixedDamageAttack) it can be powered up independently of Quina's level by playing the frog catching minigame. Potentially you could get it to hit the damage cap as soon as you obtain it, though that would require a whole lot of waiting for the frog pond to restock. - Also, Limit Glove. It can be learned as soon as Quina enters your party in Disc 1, costs 10 MP to use, and does 9999 damage, every time...as long as Quina's HP is 1 when you use it; otherwise it does nothing. Thankfully Quina has a spell to reduce any target's HP down to 1, including their own.
[Everyone Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneHasStandards): Quina's 'Eat' ability doesn't work on humans, or enemies with human-level intelligence. So they are not a cannibal.

[Extreme Omnivore](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExtremeOmnivore): The defining character trait of Qus in general. It's even a gameplay mechanic, as the way they learn their Blue Magic spells is eating a monster who knows the spell.

[The Fool](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFool): Quina has some inexplicably good survival skills; they manage to survive all of Cleyra being destroyed by apparently running down the trunk (though some other survivors pop up so clearly they weren't alone in this), and somehow swim all the way from the Outer Continent to Treno after falling in the sea.
[Fork Fencing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForkFencing): All of Quina's weapons are giant forks because they're a gourmand.

[The Friend Nobody Likes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFriendNobodyLikes): Downplayed: Quina doesn't have any close friends among the group, who mainly seem to tolerate them. When the group forms teams for the four shrines late in the game, Zidane ends up getting stuck with Quina, simply because he thinks pairing Steiner and Quina would be a bad idea. Despite this, some members of the group express positive feelings towards Quina: Zidane seems fond of them (albeit exasperatedly so), Vivi seems devastated when he thinks Quina perished in the destruction of Cleyra, and Freya (who, at the time, is preoccupied and worried about Burmecia) expresses admiration for Quina's live-in-the-moment mentality and feels like she could learn something from them.
[Funetik Aksent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FunetikAksent): As for the entire Qu race, they speak with Rome dialect in the Italian translation.

[Gameplay and Story Integration](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStoryIntegration): Quina's defining characteristic is being a [Big Eater](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigEater), and one of their abilities is to physically eat a weakened enemy to gain their abilities.

[Genius Ditz](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeniusDitz): Quina is generally pretty clueless, but they are a master chef, and surprisingly wise for such a carefree person. Notably when they give Eiko cooking advice, it's very useful.

[The Hedonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHedonist): To the point where the trait associated with their character quote is "indulgence": Quina thinks nothing about indulging their desire for food no matter the situation.
QUOTE  *I do what I want! You have problem?*
[Improbable Weapon User](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobableWeaponUser): Quina's weapons are giant dinner forks.

tropeName: Jerk with a Heart of Gold
tropeNotes: [Jerk with a Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkWithAHeartOfGold): Though Quina seems to be a self-centered hedonist most of the time they do show concern for their companions from time to time, such as consoling and offering to aid Freya as she entered her [Doomed Hometown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoomedHometown) and assuring Vivi that, black mage or no, he's still human in the ways that count.

[Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog): Though it could be argued they're just too dumb to realize what they're doing, Quina expresses interest in eating both chocobo eggs and moogles, which is pretty harsh considering they're the [Series Mascots](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SeriesMascot). The chocobo egg is particularly mean as it's being cared for by Black Mages who tell them its mother died, but Quina is undeterred and considers the idea ridiculous.

[Lethal Joke Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LethalJokeCharacter): When you first get Quina, they have *no* usable skills, a random attack damage variable, and almost no purchasable weapons. Take the time to use them properly, and you can kill almost any enemy (and some bosses) in one turn. In [The Very Definitely Final Dungeon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheVeryDefinitelyFinalDungeon), as you would expect, there are a lot of powerful enemies, but it turns out most of them are not immune to status ailments, so Quina's Mustard Bomb and Frost attacks become [One-Hit KO](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKO) moves for as little as 8 MP. Also Quina's Lvl. 5 Death spell is one of the fastest ways to kill Grand Dragons, the enemy best suited for leveling up in the endgame.

[Magikarp Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagikarpPower): As is typical for Blue Mages in the series, but Quina goes a step beyond it. Like other Blue Mages in the series (such as Strago and Quistis), Quina is at their best with a full set of spells. Unlike those two, Quina begins with no spells at all in their kit and a physical attack that gives random damage output, only making them useful as an [Item Caddy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItemCaddy) at first. That said, training Quina into having a full arsenal rewards the player with one of the best Blue Mages in the series, as Quina now can function as a better healer than Garnet or Eiko, a damage dealer only rivaled by Zidane and Freya, the ability to hit elemental weaknesses with better efficiency than Vivi, and a combination buffer and debuffer that outshines Amarant.
[Manchild](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManChild): Quina's age is apparently 89 but they have a very child-like attitude due to a sheltered upbringing.

[Older Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OlderThanTheyLook): [According to the game's Ultimania](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual), s/he's *89*. Though it's worth stating that it's specifically mentioned in-game that Quina is fairly young [by Qu standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LongLived).

[Optional Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalPartyMember): In Disc 1. [The game acknowledges if you recruit them before when you are required to go to Qu Marsh in Disc 2](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DevelopersForesight).
[Overly-Long Tongue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OverlyLongTongue): Like all the Qu Tribe, they have an enormous tongue which perpetually hangs out of their mouth.
[Plucky Comic Relief](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PluckyComicRelief): If there is a gag to happen, like thinking a swirling pit of quicksand looks yummy, they will jump into it.
[Punny Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunnyName): Quina Quen is a Japanese play on words. Quina means 'to eat', Quen means 'cannot eat'.

[Running Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RunningGag):
    - Always on the lookout for new food to try. [Even on Bran Bal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OverlyLongGag), a village of Genomes on *another planet*, Quina's only interest is finding something to eat. - They also usually wind up being left behind and surviving any disaster.

[Screw This, I'm Outta Here](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewThisImOuttaHere): If Quina participates in the defense of Cleyra, they will refuse to follow the rest of the party onto the telepod spheres because they don't like heights. When the rest of the party leaves Quina in Madain Sari while they go to the Iifa Tree, they are so offended that they simply decide to swim home.

[Supreme Chef](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SupremeChef): Quina makes delicious meals and is seen several times in a kitchen giving orders. They can also give some advice about cooking to Eiko, which makes *her* into a [Supreme Chef](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SupremeChef) herself.

[Too Dumb to Live](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooDumbToLive): Quina is eternally clueless even when the towns around the party are being destroyed and the people are fleeing in terror, yet somehow they endure. Their ability to inexplicably survive any disaster and somehow turn up later is a [Running Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RunningGag) in and of itself.
[Trademark Favorite Food](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrademarkFavoriteFood): Frogs. It's how Zidane gets them to join his cause.

[Useless Useful Spell](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UselessUsefulSpell): Quina's [Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak) is completely useless unless you're trying to learn blue magic. Their Eat skill turns into Cook, which allows them to eat a weakened enemy whose remaining HP is at 50% or less instead of the enemy need to be at 25% HP remaining. Cook serves more as a utility instead of supplement like Vivi's double casting his magic.

[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): Quina has a peculiar knack for vanishing and reappearing at the oddest times. About halfway through Disc 2, they take off after Mog to try and eat her, briefly reappears to help Eiko cook, then vanishes again until Disc 3, where they somehow end up in Treno for a brief run-in with Eiko, then ends up washing up on the shores of Lindblum where they rejoin the party. There's also no telling how they survived Cleyra being *blown up*, but a short time later they're back in the marsh catching frogs. See [Running Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RunningGag).

[You No Take Candle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouNoTakeCandle): Their speech pattern, as well as the other Qus.
QUOTE "I no can eat."
[Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionGirl): For such a young girl, she's a fairly powerful summoner.

[Anger Born of Worry](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AngerBornOfWorry): After recovering her pendant from the thieves in her village, Eiko gives Mog a scolding for running away and says something could have happened to her, but she's thankful that nothing did happen.

[Auto-Revive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AutoRevive): As long as there are Phoenix Pinions in the inventory, Eiko will summon this Eidolon when she's knocked out, also reviving any other party members in the same condition.
[Badass Adorable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassAdorable): A tiny little girl with major magical power.

[Big Sister Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigSisterMentor): Inverted in that Eiko functions as a *Little* Sister Mentor to Dagger. She gives Dagger valuable emotional support when the latter is suffering from her [Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD), such as by telling her not to feel ashamed that Vivi is dealing with his issues while she still needs time to deal with hers.
[Bratty Half-Pint](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrattyHalfPint): Growing up with moogles did little to help her social skills.
[The Chew Toy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChewToy): Not as much as Vivi, but she does have a dangling-helplessly animation that gets reused quite a bit.
[Child Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChildMage): Like Vivi, Eiko is a powerful wielder of magic despite her young age.

[Clingy Jealous Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClingyJealousGirl): She has a crush on Zidane and is quick to pick up on his attraction to Garnet, so she sets about trying to win him for herself. She's overjoyed when Garnet becomes Queen of Alexandria, because it means they can't be together and she thinks she has a shot. Amusingly enough when Zidane saves Garnet from Alexander (and they hug affectionately) it cuts to a shot of Eiko looking very annoyed.

[Competence Zone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CompetenceZone): Eiko is far more capable than a six-year-old has any right to be. In fact, we can probably say that the competence zone is six, and that all the older characters in their teens are no longer in it.

[Crippling Overspecialization](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CripplingOverspecialization): She is a [White Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage) and a summoner - but Garnet has more summons and learns most of her White Magic spells. Ergo, a party of Eiko and Garnet can easily be seen as redundant.
[Friendly Rival](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendlyRival): Despite thinking of Dagger as a rival for Zidane's love, Eiko still likes and gets along well with her.

[Gameplay and Story Integration](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStoryIntegration): Being [Wise Beyond Her Years](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WiseBeyondHerYears) and the leader of the Moogles at Madain Sari, during segments where Zidane is not with the party (such as the Desert Place or the potentially final battle against Necron), Eiko has highest priority of leading the party.
[Genki Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenkiGirl): She has a great deal of energy and is usually excited about something.
[Happily Adopted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappilyAdopted): By Cid and Hilda at the end of the game. Judging by the scene, *she* adopted *them* as her parents, and they went along with it.
[Horned Humanoid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HornedHumanoid): She has a horn because she's a summoner.

[Improbable Age](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobableAge): While most *Final Fantasy* protagonists are teenagers or young adults, Eiko pushes the envelope very low by being only six, making her one of the youngest playable characters in the franchise (not taking into account beings with abnormal lifespans or created through unusual circumstances).

[Improbable Weapon User](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobableWeaponUser): While the catapult rackets she shares with Garnet are believable enough, she also uses magic flutes in battle. She doesn't even whack people with them; she just headbutts the enemy with her horn.

[I'm Not Afraid of You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImNotAfraidOfYou): When Zidane's not selected for the final battle, but Eiko is, she's the one to rally up the party, telling Necron (who is the embodiment of *death*) that she's not afraid of him.

tropeName: I Want My Beloved to Be Happy
tropeNotes: [I Want My Beloved to Be Happy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IWantMyBelovedToBeHappy): By Disc 4, Eiko has given up on trying to wedge between Zidane and Garnet, and [instead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShipperOnDeck) becomes fixed on getting them both past their [Cannot Spit It Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CannotSpitItOut) stage.
[Last of Her Kind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastOfHerKind): She is the last survivor of her village until Dagger realizes she came from there too.

[Lethal Chef](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LethalChef): Implied to be this if cooking unsupervised. One option for cooking with her was to put an ooglop in the food.
QUOTE  Mocho: "[The last one](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoodleIncident) you made tasted so bad I thought my pompom would fall off."
[Light 'em Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightEmUp): Learns Holy.
[Little Miss Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LittleMissBadass): She's six years old, and adorable, but do not piss her off, or she will summon a giant monster to annihilate you.
[Magic Music](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicMusic): When equipped with a flute, she casts her spells by playing it. It's mostly for aesthetics, as there's no gameplay changes if she wields a racket.
[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): In Japanese, her name means "prosperous child" which is certainly fitting after she becomes the regent of Lindbulm's daughter.
[Nude-Colored Clothes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NudeColoredClothes): Turns out it was a bad idea to put a six-year-old girl in tight, flesh-colored pants.
[Plucky Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PluckyGirl): At six years old she experienced the death of her only (known) family member and is still running the village with her moogles.

[Precocious Crush](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrecociousCrush): On Zidane who is more than twice her age. While Zidane picks up on it, he never outright rejects her, but he also clearly isn't interested in her that way since she's just a child.
[Raised by Grandparents](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RaisedByGrandparents): Eiko's parents and siblings died and she was raised by her grandfather.

[Running Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RunningGag): Her back getting caught in things, causing her to dangle in the air. She even first meets the party because her overalls got caught on a branch by a cliff and Lani held her hostage by grabbing onto her wings.
[Sci-Fi Bob Haircut](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SciFiBobHaircut): Same as Garnet above, but with bangs. Though unlike Garnet, this is Eiko's hairstyle for the entire game.
[Signature Headgear](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SignatureHeadgear): Her signature yellow ribbon, which some people notice [while disregarding the horn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MundaneFantastic).
[Squishy Wizard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SquishyWizard): Great summoning magic, and the best healer in the game, but her HP is the lowest among the party members.
[Summon Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SummonMagic): She is a summoner.

[Tag Along Kid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TagAlongKid): She's the only child member of the party, not counting Vivi (who has an unusual aging cycle) and she's initially part of the group because of a crush on Zidane.
[Through His Stomach](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThroughHisStomach): Shortly after meeting him, she tries to woo Zidane by cooking him dinner. How well this goes depends on your choices.

[Troubling Unchildlike Behavior](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TroublingUnchildlikeBehavior): Her [Precocious Crush](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrecociousCrush) on Zidane. The issue isn't that it's innocent, *it's serious*, she actually pursues a romantic relationship with him and has the proper idea of how to woo a man — she cooks him a good meal, shows interest in his life, quotes romantic literature, and writes him a love letter (and even knows enough to get help from someone older and wiser than her with it). Her interest in him implicitly stems from being the last summoner after her grandfather died just the year prior, so she knows she's going to have to [rebuild the tribe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyYouCanRepopulateMyRace). Even so, she's **six**; she has no business pursuing a serious romantic relationship with as much skill and determination as she does. <sup>note </sup>  The game thankfully doesn't touch on the question of if Eiko is actually aware of the "physical" aspects of a relationship, possibly to keep her crush on Zidane from being *too* uncomfortable.
[Two First Names](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TwoFirstNames): Her last name is a common Englsh feminine name.
[Use Your Head](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UseYourHead): Her attack animation when equipped with a flute has her headbutt the enemy.

[White Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage): [White Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMagic) is her specialty, having a more potent set of spells and stats than Garnet, as she's more of a [White Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage) while Garnet's more of a [Summoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SummonMagic). Even Eiko's Eidolons reflect this: Carbuncle grants various [Status Buffs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatusBuff) that are determined by Eiko's equipped accessory, Phoenix is a powerful revival spell plus multi-target fire damage, and Madeen is a multi-target [Holy Hand Grenade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HolyHandGrenade).

[Wings Do Nothing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WingsDoNothing): Downplayed, the only time she uses her wings is when she dodges attacks. But other than that, they don't really do much. Lani even held her hostage by grabbing onto her wings.

[Wise Beyond Their Years](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WiseBeyondTheirYears): Eiko still has some growing up as far as maturity goes, but for a six-year old she is surprisingly intelligent and competent. Not only does she try to win Zidane's heart from Garnet as described above, but she lives with a band of moogles and organizes food raids from a nearby village, can handle fights with savage monsters, is well-versed in classic literature, is knowledgeable about the full history and culture of the summoner tribe, and is an effective summoner and mage. If Eiko is left in the Desert Palace when Kuja forces Zidane to split from the party, Eiko is the one who takes charge of the others to fight their way out, and she's the one Zidane asks to look after Garnet when she has her [Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD).

['90s Anti-Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NinetiesAntiHero): Being a nice person is 'incompressible' to him as Zidane spares him. The tattoos, dreadlocks, less-practical claws and fashionable facial hair add to the 'cool' factor. Him saying 'Some call me the Flaming Amarant.' shows he doesn't mind being seen as this.

[Advertised Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdvertisedExtra): He is the last person to join the heroes and doesn't have a personal stake in the quest other than a [Worthy Opponent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent) thing with Zidane that is only briefly touched on, yet he has plenty of official artwork and is even on the cover!
[Afro Asskicker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AfroAsskicker): It's really a mass of dreads, but his in-game model looks more like an afro.

[Amazing Technicolor Population](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmazingTechnicolorPopulation): For some reason, Amarant's skin is blue. [Yoshitaka Amano](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/YoshitakaAmano) depicts him with a more conventional skin color.

[Ambiguously Human](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguouslyHuman): Amarant seems, in every way, like a normal human...except for the blue skin. It's possible he's part of a human subspecies of some kind like the summoners, but it's never made explicit in-game.
[Badass Boast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBoast): *Introducing himself* is arguably this with the lofty title he uses, given the origin of his name.
[Barbie Doll Anatomy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarbieDollAnatomy): He's naked in his Trance form, but not scandalous.
[Bounty Hunter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BountyHunter): Hired by Brahne to track down Garnet's party.
[Brutal Honesty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrutalHonesty): He doesn't mince any words when he gives his thoughts on things.
[Chekhov's Gunman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChekhovsGunman): He appears on a wanted poster in Treno near the start of disc 2, and joins near the end of that same disc.

[Combat Medic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatMedic): Half of Amarant's special abilities center around hurting his enemies. The other half center around reviving his fallen allies, healing them, or allowing them to revive after they're knocked out. He's also the only warrior-type who can equip the Healer specialization, in which striking a character *restores* their HP. Plus, the fact that his Flair abilities don't technically count as magic make him an ideal character to take to the magic-blocking Oeilvert. Why does the guy who disdains teamwork have so many skills revolving around healing people? His Character Development involves getting over his [Ineffectual Loner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IneffectualLoner) status. His abilities really would be more useful as part of a team.

[Comes Great Responsibility](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ComesGreatResponsibility): When he confronts the Fire Guardian, Amarant realizes that he's been wasting his power by simply seeking out people to fight, instead of finding beneficial ways to use it.
[The Comically Serious](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheComicallySerious): Eiko (unintentionally) uses him as her hired muscle when the gang travels to Treno. It's a pretty great sequence altogether.
[Damage-Increasing Debuff](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DamageIncreasingDebuff): Amarant's Curse inflicts a target with a elemental weakness. They're random, but can be used repeatedly to stack.

[Don't You Dare Pity Me!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DontYouDarePityMe): He's a proud man and doesn't accept mercy gracefully. He would rather have had Zidane kill him when he lost their duel than receive mercy.

[The Dreaded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDreaded): Despite having a price on his head, Amarant is completely at ease walking through Treno. Judging by Alleyway Jack's reaction, this is because all of Treno's thieves, bounty hunters, and lowlifes are too scared of him to try and claim the reward.
[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): He's called Salamander in the Japanese version, Tarask in the French version, and Mahagon in the German version.
[Duel Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelBoss): Zidane has to fight him one-on-one.

[Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards): Even though he has been hired to defeat the party and get Dagger's pendant, he tells Lani that he doesn't work with "hostage-taking scumbags" when she kidnaps Eiko.

[The Faceless](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFaceless): There is *maybe* one good picture that shows his face in the entirety of FFIX's official artwork and even it is less than ideal. His Afro always hides his eyes, too.

[Fantasy Character Classes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasyCharacterClasses): Combination of [the Monk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BareFistedMonk) and the Ninja, and despite the general versatility drop that usually accompanies Red Mage classes in a Final Fantasy game, Amarant's diverse uses just make him that much more viable as the other characters drift into [Crippling Overspecialization](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CripplingOverspecialization).

[Friend to All Children](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendToAllChildren): Implied. His interactions with Eiko are the most commonly cited, but he's also the first to comfort an motion sick Vivi while riding the experimental Hilda Garde 2.

[Gameplay and Story Integration](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStoryIntegration): When he enters Trance, his Flair abilities can now target multiple enemies or party members. The latter reflects Amarant's new understanding of working as a team and understanding friendship.
[Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn): Introduced as a bounty hunter hired by the queen, he soon joins the heroes.
[Hidden Eyes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenEyes): They're hidden by his hair or his posture.

[Honor Before Reason](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HonorBeforeReason): He demands that Zidane *kill* him after losing a one-on-one duel, while he probably would have won if only he hadn't sent Lani away and threw away their hostage.

[Ineffectual Loner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IneffectualLoner): Downplayed. He's presumably successful in his career because he's [The Dreaded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDreaded) but in the game itself he works better in a team.

[I Work Alone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IWorkAlone): He tries to enforce this at Ipsen Castle by racing against Zidane. He beats him... but gets caught in a trap when he tries to leave the castle, leading Zidane to come rescue him.

[Jack of All Stats](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JackOfAllStats): Amarant is easily the most versatile member of the team, being a decent attacker with access to healing and magical attack skills, but his performance in these areas isn't quite as good as the more specialized characters. Not that it matters, since he's still one of the best characters in the game. His Chakra skill is one of the most useful skills, as it heals both HP and MP for a decent amount and Aura casts Regen and Auto-Life. The only drawback is that all of his skills are single target, except in Trance where they become all-target.
[Kamehame Hadoken](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KamehameHadoken): His No Mercy skill him blast a ball of energy with just one hand.
[Noble Demon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NobleDemon): He may be a dreaded bounty hunter but he doesn't take hostages.

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): Several.
    - When Amarant turns on Lani at the end of Disc 2, claiming that he refuses to work with "hostage-taking scumbags." - There's also his cute vignettes with Eiko in Treno and giving Vivi advice on how to avoid airsickness. - At one point, a [Bounty Hunter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BountyHunter) tries to capture Eiko, thinking she might serve as a weakness to Amarant, his target. Amarant wasn't even present when he attempted (and failed) the stunt, so we're not sure of how Amarant would react.
[Power Fist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerFist): A few of his weapons are knuckledusters.

[The Power of Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePowerOfFriendship): When Zidane risks his life to save Amarant for no personal gain, Amarant gets a better understanding of what friendship means, to the point the player even gets to *see* his victory pose. One of the running themes of the game is that characters who are going through emotional struggles or trauma will not enter their victory pose and maintain their battle stance all the way through the victory theme. Amarant starts off and stays that way up until this point.
[Red Baron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedBaron): Introduces himself as the "Flaming Amarant" shortly after you name him.

[Rings of Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RingsOfDeath): Unlike most *[Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/FinalFantasy)* ninjas, who throw shurikens at their enemies, Amarant throws chakrams instead.

[Self-Deprecation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SelfDeprecation): When facing the Fire Guardian, he says she reminds him of a "loser" he once knew- namely, his past self. Freya immediately understands what Amarant is getting at.
[Too Many Belts](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooManyBelts): He not only wears a belt around his waist, but one each around his arms too. Oddly they're all too long with the excess length hanging down.
[Walking the Earth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingTheEarth): Amarant's travelling at the end of the game, and he doesn't seem to mind.

[What the Hell, Hero?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero): He calls Zidane out on this in Terra after Zidane pushes everyone away when just hours ago, he was scolding Amarant for trying to be a tough guy loner.
[Wolverine Claws](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WolverineClaws): The majority of his weapons are claws.

[Action Politician](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionPolitician): She may just be lounging for 90% of her screen-time, but she is lounging in her battle-ship perched directly over her invasion forces; And then front and center once she gains Garnet’s Eidolons.
[Adipose Regina](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdiposeRex): A bloated blue queen. If you ever see her walk, it will be a waddle.

[Alas, Poor Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlasPoorVillain): In spite of all the atrocities she did, Garnet still loses her mother when she dies. Although it's a little played with. While Garnet is (understandably) saddened by her death, Vivi on the other hand feels sad for Garnet, not really for Brahne. However, she was certainly the victim of [The Corruption](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCorruption) thanks to the mists, so this trope still counts.
[Amazing Technicolor Population](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmazingTechnicolorPopulation): Her bright blue skin stands out.

[Arc Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArcVillain): For The Mist Continent, as she is introduced just after the tutorial stages and is the biggest bad available until the enigmatic Kuja makes his appearance.

[Asshole Victim](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AssholeVictim): After everything she's done, she ends up being killed by Kuja after she betrays and tries to kill him. [Averted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AvertedTrope), as both Garnet and the people of Alexandria still mourn for her, choosing to remember all the good Brahne did prior to her descent into madness, though Vivi believes she deserved it and only mourns for Garnet's sake.

[Big Bad Ensemble](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadEnsemble): She views herself and Kuja as this, believing that they are in an alliance of convenience and fully intending to kill him as a rival to her bid to [Take Over the World](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeOverTheWorld) once her power is cemented.  (SPOILER) [It goes about as well as you'd expect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FailureIsTheOnlyOption) .

[Big Bad Wannabe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadWannabe): She's a threat to the entire Mist Continent, and she certainly thinks that she holds superior power over Kuja,  (SPOILER) but it ultimately turns out that she was the [Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn) of Kuja's and Garland's plan all along. When she tries to get rid of Kuja, she gets killed .
[Brawn Hilda](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrawnHilda): Her character design was clearly inspired by this trope given her bloated figure and the horns in her headgear.

[Chekhov's Gunman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChekhovsGunman): After being dispatched at the end of Disc 2, she returns in a sense on Disc 3, when Kuja reveals that her powerful spirit, which he has absorbed, was the key catalyst he needed to enter Trance.

[Cool Airship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolAirship): The *Red Rose*, Brahne's luxury flagship. When it's not being used as a mobile observation post for Her Highness, it's being used to teleport black mages directly into combat zones.

[Death Equals Redemption](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathEqualsRedemption): When she's dying on the beaches of the Outer Continent, Brahne realizes that she is finally free of the terrible greed that was driving her, and makes peace with Garnet before she dies.
[Disc-One Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneFinalBoss): Believed to be the main villain until Kuja removes her from the equation.
[Dying as Yourself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DyingAsYourself): Finally manages to break free of her greed in the last moments before she dies.
[Evil Laugh](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilLaugh): Bwahahaha!

[Evil Plan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilPlan): [Take Over the World](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeOverTheWorld) out of sheer greed. Once she's stopped at the end of disc 2, peace returns to the Mist Continent until Kuja stirs things up again.
[Face–Heel Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceHeelTurn): She underwent one prior to the beginning of the game. Not everyone is aware of it until she attacks Burmecia.

[Fat Bitch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FatBitch): Her cruelty is rivalled only by her size. Kuja often derisively calls her the "elephant lady" while saying that he only gave her the power she needed to act on her selfish ambitions.

tropeName: God Save Us from the Queen!
tropeNotes: [God Save Us from the Queen!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodSaveUsFromTheQueen): She is a horrid and evil monarch if there was ever one. Interestingly, it's mostly subverted with her own subjects, as she treats them rather well even after she starts her [Evil Plan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilPlan). They are unaware of her [Evil Plan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilPlan) and see her as [The High Queen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHighQueen), due to her having been one of those before she went mad. Even after her death, her people still mourn her due to the justness she formerly had.
[Gonk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Gonk): Brahne has blue skin, tiny black eyes, and a big purple nose.

[Good Parents](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodParents): [She obviously isn't one anymore](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OffingTheOffspring), but Garnet mentions several times that Brahne and her husband were loving parents when she was a child (before the king's death). Brahne herself later reminisces that watching a play with Garnet and her husband was one of the last times she was truly happy.

[Happily Married](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappilyMarried): With [her husband the King of Alexandria](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PosthumousCharacter), before his death. It's implied he was also her [Morality Chain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoralityChain). Garnet mentions that she started to act differently after his death.

[The High Queen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHighQueen): While she is undeniably evil during the events of the game and certainly lacks the beauty aspect, it's reflected that before her husband died and Kuja showed up, she was a fair and loved ruler. An NPC remarks that the wreath of roses on her grave shows the people of Alexandria will remember her fondly for those better days.
[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): "Queen of the Abyss."
[The Lost Lenore](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLostLenore): It's implied that grief over losing her husband is what allowed Kuja to start manipulating her.

[Made of Iron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadeOfIron): Was attacked *point blank* by Bahamut's Megaflare, remained able and conscious enough to get to her ship's escape pod as it was sinking, and held on long enough to apologize to her daughter and pass the throne to her with her dying breath.

[More than Mind Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreThanMindControl): Brahne's severe personality shift from [kind and beloved ruler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHighQueen) to [greedy warmonger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodSaveUsFromTheQueen) is implied to be due to a combination of her husband's death emotionally destabilizing her and Kuja's manipulations.
QUOTE  **Kuja**: The war was my fault? No, no! Your mother wanted it! All I did was give her a little push!
[Not Herself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotHerself): Garnet, Cid and Beatrix all note that, following her husband's death, Brahne became much more erratic, callous, and greedy.

[Obviously Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObviouslyEvil): The vampiresque skin and mammoth size make players uncomfortable with trusting her. [Played With](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayedWith) in that this is presumably her natural appearance, but her evil-ness is a new trait.

[Offing the Offspring](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OffingTheOffspring): She was planning to have Garnet killed for treason after she extracted the eidolons from her and had [no further need for her](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveOutlivedYourUsefulness), but Zidane manages to put a stop to it.

[Outliving One's Offspring](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutlivingOnesOffspring): Brahne's biological daughter died ten years ago. When an identical stranger washed up on the castle's docks, Brahne and her husband adopted the girl as a [Replacement Goldfish](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReplacementGoldfish).

[Royals Who Actually Do Something](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalsWhoActuallyDoSomething): Brahne deserves special mention for showing up *in person* every time her army conquers another country and carrying out the Eidolon summoning herself. However, also unlike most other examples, this backfires when Kuja takes control of Bahamut and uses it to assassinate her. Maybe the other royals had the right idea after all.
[The Unfought](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfought): There is no boss battle with her in it.

[Ungrateful Bitch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UngratefulBitch): She eagerly takes Cleyra's jewel from Beatrix without even thanking her. Despite her [Blind Obedience](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlindObedience) to Brahne, Beatrix is offended.
QUOTE **Beatrix**: Not even a word of gratitude...
[Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn): Of Kuja, and by proxy Garland. Both of them used her war and greed to fulfill their own objectives.

[Walking Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingSpoiler): Before the player has a grasp of the plot, it's clear that she is a major villain due to [her appearance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObviouslyEvil). This may have been intended to have been the disc 1 twist as well.

[You Have Outlived Your Usefulness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveOutlivedYourUsefulness):
    - Planned to have Garnet executed after sapping all of her eidolons from her. - She also tries to pull this on Kuja after conquering the Mist Continent, but has the tables turned on her when Kuja takes control of Bahamut using the Invincible, and is disposed of herself.
[Agent Peacock](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AgentPeacock): His clothes are outrageous, even for a Final Fantasy villain.
[All According to Plan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllAccordingToPlan): As noted below, nearly these exact words are his catchphrase. However, Kuja wasn't quite as in control as he thought...
[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): The Woobie variety; you'd be pretty messed up with that kind of backstory too.
[Arch-Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArchEnemy): To Zidane. Kuja is unable to see the value of anything but himself, while Zidane has a motto to help anyone who needs it.

[Arms Dealer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArmsDealer): Provides Brahne with the means to create Black Mages and summon Eidolons. This lasts up until the end of the second disc, whereupon he kills Brahne and reveals that the whole thing was just an act to hide his true agenda.

[Barred from the Afterlife](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarredFromTheAfterlife): Part of the reason Kuja has nothing to lose and everything to gain by attempting to conquer Gaia and Terra and being an archetypal villain. Quite simply, losing to Garland means he loses his life *and* his soul.
QUOTE "I need an eidolon more powerful than Alexander! An eidolon with the power to bury Garland! His powers are so incredible; I cannot even come close. I must destroy him before Terra's plan is activated, or my soul will no longer be my own! Who cares if she lives? I want that eidolon!"

[Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad): He is the power behind Brahne and the one stirring up all the game's conflict. Then you find out that he was just [The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon) to the *real* villain, Garland...right up until the end of disc three, when he backstabs Garland and becomes a *real* [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad).

[Born as an Adult](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BornAsAnAdult): According to creation materials. This is the reason for Kuja's [Psychopathic Manchild](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychopathicManchild) tendencies, and why Garland chose to have Zidane start as an infant: Zidane was able to grow and mature enough to enter [Trance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperMode), while Kuja, who was created as an adult, could never develop past his initial thought process and thus never truly change.

[Cain and Abel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CainAndAbel): Cain to Zidane's Abel because he is the evil and treacherous son who tries to kill his brother *and* his father. However, Zidane isn't fond of Dad either.

[Camp Straight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CampStraight): Kuja has a lot of effeminate mannerisms (though he still uses the masculine pronoun "boku" in Japanese), but the only character he flirts with is Garnet.

[Card-Carrying Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CardCarryingVillain): Kuja is quite aware he's the villain of this tale and has no problem playing his part as such.
QUOTE **Garnet:** Don't you feel anything!? Taking the lives of so many... 
**Kuja:** Spare me the lecture. Lives come and go all the time. What's the big deal?
[Character Catchphrase](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterCatchphrase): "Everything is going according to plan..."

[Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment): With the possible exception of [Golbez](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIV), who was actually [Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy), Kuja has the distinction of being the first and only *[Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/FinalFantasy)* [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) to undergo some personality changes and end up redeeming himself. Some FF villains, if they receive any development, usually grow worse as time passes, and in the case of Sephiroth, needed more than one game to develop.

[The Chessmaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChessmaster): He's in control of many events early in the game, but later things start to get out of his hands. Fortunately for him, he plays a good game of [Xanatos Speed Chess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/XanatosSpeedChess), so he still stays on top of things...up until the fourth disc, when he gives up on strategy altogether and descends into world-destroying lunacy.

[Chronic Backstabbing Disorder](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChronicBackstabbingDisorder): All of his business partners are only stepping stones to something bigger and he casts them aside when they are no longer needed. All of this is to betray his creator, Garland, who he is nominally working for.

[Composite Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CompositeCharacter): Kuja either imitates or mirrors every single one of the main villains of the Final Fantasy series in some way - fitting for a game designed as one giant [Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag).
    - Both he and the original Garland from *[Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyI)* kidnap a Princess named Sarah, as Sarah is Garnet's real name. - Both he and Emperor Mateus from *[Final Fantasy II](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyII)* kidnap a woman named Hilda and use a giant powerful airship. - Both he and Xande from *[Final Fantasy III](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIII)* throw a [Suicidal Cosmic Temper Tantrum](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuicidalCosmicTemperTantrum) upon finding out that they are mortal. - Both he and Golbez from *[Final Fantasy IV](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIV)* are related to the protagonist of their respective games. They're also both from a different planet than the one the game starts on. - Both he and Exdeath from *[Final Fantasy V](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyV)* draw their powers from a tree made of souls. - Both he and Kefka from *[Final Fantasy VI](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVI)* start out as underlings of an Emperor/Queen, responsible for giving the powers that caused villainy to be begin with, who they eventually overthrow and murder. Kuja also kills Garland in the same way Kefka kills Emperor Gestahl - kicking them off a ledge a-la-Sparta. Their plans also involve using the powers of Eidolons. - Both he and Sephiroth from *[Final Fantasy VII](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVII)* use their protagonist as a [MacGuffin Delivery Service](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MacGuffinDeliveryService). They are both also products of experimentation, although Kuja is far more "artificial" than Sephiroth as a whole. And, of course, they're both of the [White Hair, Black Heart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteHairBlackHeart) archetype. - Both he and Ultimecia from *[Final Fantasy VIII](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVIII)* reside in a time distortion for their final battle. Ultimecia is found in her castle after time has been compressed, while Kuja is found in Memoria, which is a physical manifestation of the planet's memories. - Both he and Ultima from *[Final Fantasy Tactics](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyTactics)* have masterminded large scale conflicts between nations of the world in order to further their own plans.

[Cool Airship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolAirship): Kuja is in possession of Regent Cid's prototype airship, the Hilda Garde, and uses it throughout Disc 3 to ferry both himself and his captives across Gaia.

[Dark Messiah](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkMessiah): In contrast to Zidane's [Anti-Anti-Christ](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiAntichrist). Mikoto stated that, although what Kuja did was wrong, he nonetheless brought hope for the Genomes in defying their original purpose and proving that their lives *weren't* meaningless at all.
[Death Trap](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathTrap): Employs this on the party when holding them captive in his Desert Palace. He didn't really care if they lived or died — it was just for the fun of it.

[Didn't See That Coming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidntSeeThatComing): Kuja's clever, smart, and powerful but he's not omniscient. He can plan for some elements like Queen Brahne turning on him because he knows of her greed, but extreme factors outside of what he thought could happen will catch him off guard. It's one of the reasons he's forced to display his skill at [Xanatos Speed Chess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/XanatosSpeedChess). Of note, is the moment when Garland shows up in the *Invincible* and destroys Alexander (the single goal of Kuja's entire [Evil Plan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilPlan)) moments before Kuja is about to enslave him.

[Disc-One Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneFinalBoss): Kuja is the last boss fight on Disc 3, and the sole opponent confronted between the game's POTN on Disc 4 and the [True Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrueFinalBoss).

[Dragon Rider](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DragonRider): Uses a Silver Dragon as a mount. It actually belongs to Garland; following the Battle of Alexandria, Garland presumably revoked it because Kuja is never seen using it again. However, there's that [Cool Airship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolAirship) back at his hangar.
[Dude Looks Like a Lady](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DudeLooksLikeALady): Yes, despite the girly face, effeminate mannerisms and fashion style, he is in fact a *he*.

[Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards): He admits out of her sight that Brahne disgusts him. However, given what sort of evil deeds Kuja himself is doing, it may be more about [Brahne's physical appearance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdiposeRex) than her personality.

[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart):
    - To Zidane. Both are genomes and men of theater, but while Zidane is a lovable rogue with a heart of gold, whose motto in life is "Do you need a reason to help anyone?", Kuja is a selfish, vain individual that doesn't care about anyone but himself, using anyone as pawns for his plans. - He's also this to Vivi. Both are artificial beings who were made to invade other places and they both face the revelation that they're going to be dying much sooner than they anticipated. However, the physically childish Vivi chooses to give his life meaning by helping others with what little time he has left and leaving behind new life to continue his legacy while the older-looking Kuja snaps and decides the entire world is going down with him.

[Evil Feels Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilFeelsGood): Rejecting the idea of being a tool created to serve and have no freedom of his own prompted Kuja to instead go toward the extreme opposite spectrum and develop a *massive* ego and selfish attitude. Further, he found that Garland was willing to overlook his many self-indulgences as long as Kuja used them to sow discord, death and disharmony. Kuja grew a taste for this type of thing very quickly and before long was more than willing to cast himself as a villain because it was something he was uniquely good at, something that brought him power and solace, and was also the purest way he could express himself.

[Evil Is Cool](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsCool): Invoked. Kuja believes this trope utterly. As stated in game, all of his villainous theatrics hide the heart of a cruel and tortured soul. Acting like a [Card-Carrying Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CardCarryingVillain) is just an ego boost to make him feel smugly superior to everyone else.
[Evil Plan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilPlan): He seems like a simple arms dealer for a queen, but in reality, he's using her to gather power for himself so he can overthrow his creator.
[Evil Redhead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilRedhead): When Kuja achieves Trance, his hair changes from white to blood red. The Ultimania guide claims that this is his real hair color.

[Faux Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FauxAffablyEvil): As poetic, sophisticated, and well-groomed as he seems to be, it is just an act to prove to himself and others that he's superior to normal people. In reality he's cruel, selfish, and cunning, and starts to show his true colors in Disc 3 when things don't go just as he wanted.

[The Fighting Narcissist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFightingNarcissist): Kuja is not only handsome to the point of beauty, but he's perfectly aware of it and flaunts it. He's also a terrifically powerful mage who can kick the party's ass with ease and enjoys doing so to prove his superiority to them.

[Flawed Prototype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlawedPrototype): Subverted. Garland ultimately admits that Kuja is vastly more effective than he'd ever thought possible. It's still implied that due to Kuja being one of the first Genomes, his lifespan will ultimately be much shorter than those who come after him (such as Zidane).

[Freudian Excuse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FreudianExcuse): Alright, picture this: You're one of an entire race of mindless [Slave Mooks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlaveMooks) that were created only to follow orders and work without end, have *zero* individuality or self-awareness, and are easy to discard and replace. Oh, except you were given individuality by accident, so you're aware of how much this existence sucks. Fortunately, your Creator will let you keep your mind, but only if you prove that you're effective at killing as many people as possible. You're allowed total and complete freedom, and can amass as much wealth, power, and luxury as you choose, just as long as it's used to [wipe out the entire population](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KillAllHumans) of the only world where that stuff matters. Also, keep in mind that even if you succeed at your job, [you're going to be discarded and replaced](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveOutlivedYourUsefulness) [while an even better version of you does what you couldn't.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReplacementMooks) Oh, and when that happens, [you won't get to have a soul anymore](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeaderThanDead), as it will be [cleansed and recycled for someone else to have long after you're gone.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YourSoulIsMine) Even Zidane feels sympathy for him at the end, and says he might have done the same thing in his place.

[Genre Savvy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenreSavvy): In his free time, Kuja is a big fan of literature and theater. He *purposefully* invokes villainous tropes (such as [I Have Your Wife](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IHaveYourWife), [MacGuffin Delivery Service](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MacGuffinDeliveryService), and [I Lied](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ILied)), mentioning several times that he is carrying out his plans like acts of a play. And this *works*, allowing him to manipulate the heroes almost until the end.
[Hartman Hips](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HartmanHips): Rare male example; Kuja's outfit prominently emphasizes his hips.
[I Have Your Wife](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IHaveYourWife): When Kuja kidnaps the entire party to send Zidane on an errand, which leads directly to [I Lied](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ILied) below.

[I Lied](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ILied): As soon as Zidane's gone to fetch an artifact for him, he tries to kill the rest of the party anyway, [just because it's more fun that way.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForTheEvulz)

[Inferiority Superiority Complex](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InferioritySuperiorityComplex): The main reason Kuja acts like he's smarter and prettier and just better than other people is because he's deeply insecure over the fact he really isn't any of those things and is just a [Flawed Prototype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlawedPrototype).

[It's All About Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsAllAboutMe): His primary justification for his omnicidal tendencies from the end of disc 3 onwards. Justified in-universe, as Kuja was *created* as a [Manchild](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManChild) unable to process any emotion other than the basic Id and self-interest. Further, unlike the other characters, he has no hope of an afterlife and his soul and memories will be wiped clean for usage by another Genome if they don't just vanish entirely.

[Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog): He snaps at the sentient Black Mages that he doesn't care what their numbers are, showing no regard for their individuality and treating them the same as the mindless ones. Later, while trying to steal Eiko's eidolons, he's warned that the process might kill her- only for Kuja to demand that the extraction process continue; the same scene also features Kuja ordering Zorn and Thorn to kill Mog—*a moogle*—because she was in the way.

[Lack of Empathy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LackOfEmpathy): Considering the type of environment in which he was created and the purpose he was created for, it's no surprise that he never developed the ability to feel for others.
QUOTE "Spare me the lecture. Lives come and go all the time. What's the big deal?"

[Laughing Mad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaughingMad): His reaction immediately after Garland tells him that his lifespan is critically limited is hysteric laughter because it signals his mental breaking point.

[Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak): Becomes a major plot point halfway through the game. After he sees Mog transform into an Eidolon due to him wanting to protect Eiko, Kuja gets a ["Eureka!" Moment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EurekaMoment) where he realizes that it would be far easier to gain power by simply letting Zidane and his party beat the crap out of him than to try extracting [Summon Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SummonMagic) from Eiko. Once Kuja enters Trance for the first time, he soundly defeats the party with his ultimate magic spell, Ultima.
    - As a [Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil) to Zidane, it is implied that FF9's equivalent of the Ultima spell that Kuja uses isn't a naturally learned spell, but a unique magic attack that's the latter's equivalent of Zidane's Dyne skill, Grand Lethal since it's only used by him in Trance.

[Made of Iron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadeOfIron): For such a fancy and camp villain, Kuja is remarkably physically resiliant: getting caught in a blast from Bahamut does little more than give him a cut on his forehead. This may be a case of [Gameplay and Story Integration](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStoryIntegration), as Kuja's stats when fought as a boss a full disc later give him a boatload of HP (42,382 to be precise), far more than Bahamut could deplete.

[Manipulative Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManipulativeBastard): The problems of Disc 1 and 2 are all his manipulations, in particular that of Queen Brahne. All he did was prey on Brahne's greed and she does all the rest. Even after her death, he then sets his sights on Alexandria, knowing full well Garnet's not on his level. Despite Garland beating him to the punch on destroying Alexandria, Kuja still effectively vanquishes the four major kingdoms of the Mist Continent with very little effort. Even during Disc 3, he still manipulates the party into doing most of his dirty work for him. It's only after he becomes the most powerful entity in the setting that he takes action head-on, and shortly after, he loses his sanity and seeks to destroy reality while on a rage-induced tantrum.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName):
    - In Hindu cosmology, Kuja is the name of Mars, the red planet, and means "born of the earth" — Terra, shown as a red planet, is Latin for earth. Mars is also the Roman god of war. All in all, Kuja's name reflects exactly what he is — a Genome created by Garland and Terra to create war and destruction on Gaia. - In Japanese, *kuja*ku means "peacock." After seeing how he dresses, you shouldn't need help seeing how that one fits.

[Minor Injury Overreaction](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MinorInjuryOverreaction): After [tanking a few blasts from Bahamut](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OH3Is0k_eqg), Kuja smirks until he notices that he'd gotten a cut on his forehead...and then laughs, *praising* the dragon for managing to injure him slightly. QUOTE **Kuja:** Blood? Ahahah! Bahamut...power, mobility...You are truly the best! You even hurt me...a little.

[Opportunistic Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OpportunisticBastard): From Disc 3 onward. In the first two discs, Kuja had a true [Evil Plan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilPlan), but it gets foiled the second that his boss, Garland, decides that [he has outlived his usefulness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveOutlivedYourUsefulness). Kuja then goes into hiding and, with his treachery revealed, has no choice but to acquire power any means he can. He tries a few things that also fail, before opportunity shines and one of the good guys taps into their [Super Mode](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperMode) right in front of him. From that moment on, his plan is to let the heroes fight both him and Garland, and win, and then invoke his own [Super Mode](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperMode) *permanently*. At that point, Kuja had everything he needed to take over the world...except time.
[Person of Mass Destruction](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PersonOfMassDestruction): When armed with the power of Trance he is capable of bringing worlds to an end.
[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): Hilda mentions that despite his soul being full of hatred, Kuja was nothing but polite to her. He even tells her his plans without her ever asking.

[Pre-Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PreFinalBoss): Trance Kuja is fought immediately before Necron. There is a small break between the battles, however it only serves to allow the player to tinker with their party before the final battle.

[Psychopathic Manchild](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychopathicManchild): While his insanity doesn't manifest until the end of Disc 3, Kuja nonetheless is mentally a child pretending to be an adult. He puts on exaggerated efforts to seem sophisticated and intelligent to assert his individuality, is very narcissistic and selfish, and is prone to quickly losing his temper when he doesn't get his way. According to creation materials, this is why Garland created Zidane as a baby — he would be able to grow and mature in order to develop the complex emotions needed to enter [Trance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperMode), while Kuja was created as an adult and never matured emotionally beyond the young mindsets of regular Genomes. This is the same reason he had to absorb Gaian souls to enter a Trance at the end of Disc 3, Kuja's emotional state is too simplistic to do it himself.

[Psycho Prototype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychoPrototype): Inadvertently, to Zidane. When Kuja displayed a particularly strong will and Garland realized there might be a use for such a Genome, he purposefully created Zidane to be a more effective version of Kuja.

tropeName: Put Them All Out of My Misery
tropeNotes: [Put Them All Out of My Misery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PutThemAllOutOfMyMisery): His main reason for deciding to destroy existence isn't just to destroy it for the sake of destroying it, but because he refuses to let the world exist if he can't be part of it.
[Recurring Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RecurringBoss): Kuja is fought at the end of the final two discs, and the second encounter comes prior to Necron.

[Redemption Equals Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedemptionEqualsDeath): He saves the heroes from Necron, and Zidane later goes back to return the favor. When the Iifa Tree collapses around the two of them, Kuja pushes Zidane out of the way, presumably killing himself.

[Reveling in the New Form](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RevelingInTheNewForm): In the finale of Disc 3, Kuja is able to attain the power of [Trance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperMode) and transforms at the end of his boss battle, becoming an eerily beautiful [Humanoid Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumanoidAbomination) covered in red feathers and blessed with even greater magical powers. Immediately glorying in his new state, he casually mops the floor with the player characters, then spends the next scene gloating over his magnificent new form and everything he plans to do with it.

[Sliding Scale of Villain Effectiveness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlidingScaleOfVillainEffectiveness): He is securely locked at "High" for the majority of the story. He has a large number of wins, and even when he loses and gets knocked down a rung or two, he still manages to recover quickly. At the end of the game, he shoots up to Infinite. Thanks to [Heads I Win, Tails You Lose](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeadsIWinTailsYouLose), even when the player wins a battle against him, one Ultima later and the party is defeated anyway. He even manages to damage the Original Crystal, as per his original intent. The only reason he fails to destroy everything is because he had no idea that Necron existed and needed to destroy reality himself in order for Crystal to truly be undone. In short, Kuja manages to execute every single goal he strove for in the story, and is only stopped at the very end when he's too insane to care about strategy anymore (which the heroes had no part in causing).

[Sliding Scale of Villain Threat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlidingScaleOfVillainThreat): He actually reaches every single tier at some point within the plot. Kuja starts as a personal foe (for Garnet), becomes a city-scale threat (manipulating the queen), then a province-level threat (commanding an army of Black Mages), then a country-level threat (attacking Alexandria with Eidolons), then for a while he becomes a personal-level threat again (kidnapping the party), then he shoots all the way up to global (attempts to conquer Terra and Gaea), then multiplanetary/galactic (blasts Terra off the map), then multiversal (tries to destroy the Original Crystal).

[The Social Darwinist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSocialDarwinist): Given Garland's intended use for him it's easy to see how he developed this mindset. The only reason why Kuja wasn't put down the moment he showed signs of instability was because Garland believed that he might be useful — at least until a stronger Genome was available to replace him, whereupon he'd simply be disposed of. Thus, gaining power strong enough to overpower that hypothetical genome and eventually overthrow Garland was the only way for Kuja to ensure his survival.
QUOTE "The weak lose their freedom to the strong. Such is the way of the strong. And it is the providence of nature that only the strong survive."
[The Starscream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStarscream): He works as a pointman for Garland on Terra to prepare for his creator's evil plan. Then he betrayed him at the first opportunity.

[Stripperific](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Stripperific): The guy wears a steel thong. Being related to Zidane and other Genomes, fans would often joke, "Where would he hide his tail?" More justified than usual since he believed himself to be immortal, and thus had no need for more protective clothing.

[Suicidal Cosmic Temper Tantrum](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuicidalCosmicTemperTantrum): Emphasis on the temper tantrum part, given his incredibly childish and selfish motivation for deciding to do this. It's basically like this: "Waahh! I don't get to live forever! I wanna live forever! The world doesn't get to live at all if I can't get to live forever!"

[Super Mode](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperMode): He absorbs the captive Gaian souls on the *Invincible* so he can use their negative emotions to enter a Trance of his own. It's so strong it lasts the whole rest of the game.

[Terms of Endangerment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TermsOfEndangerment): He's constantly using pet names for people even as he attacks them or is plotting against them. Brahne is "the elephant lady", Garnet is "[his] canary", and so forth.

[Villainous Breakdown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousBreakdown): When he finds out that he has a limited lifespan he stops pretending to be sophisticated and composed and just grabs power and wrecks stuff. Doesn't help that Garland basically called him worthless and he realized, to him, he was [just like the Black Mages he previously spent mocking and abusing.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreWhatYouHate)

[White Hair, Black Heart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteHairBlackHeart): Young, long white hair, and evil in a suave, cultured sort of way. The Ultimania guide implies that Kuja dyed his hair white to distance himself from his origins.

[Wicked Cultured](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WickedCultured): Lives in a beautifully sculpted palace of marble and stained glass, and he's a fan of Lord Avon's plays to boot. He also imprisons people in his palace and puts them in death traps.
[Woobie, Destroyer of Worlds](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WoobieDestroyerOfWorlds): His messed up childhood is the reason he goes all omnicidal.
[Would Hurt a Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WouldHurtAChild): He plans on extracting Eiko's Eidolons even if it kills her.

[Xanatos Gambit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/XanatosGambit): Once Kuja discovers the power of Trance, he forms a plan for it. With Garland out of the way, Kuja attacks Zidane to provoke him in fighting back. Should Kuja manage to win the fight, Zidane is defeated and Kuja would get his revenge. If Kuja loses, he gets the power of Trance to annihilate Zidane and his friends anyway. Once he finds out about his limited lifespan, he doesn't take the news well.

[Xanatos Speed Chess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/XanatosSpeedChess): Kuja is a *master* at this, which is rather rare compared to some [less-active villains](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OrcusOnHisThrone) of FF-series tradition. Garland knew Kuja was going to betray him a long time ago, and took steps to prepare for it. This surprises and scares the hell out of Kuja when he realizes it, and he has to completely scrap his entire [Evil Plan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilPlan) and start from scratch. He then revises it *again* when presented with a [Spanner in the Works](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpannerInTheWorks) in the form of a [little moogle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassAdorable).

[Your Days Are Numbered](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YourDaysAreNumbered): Kuja was made powerful, yes, but also immature; the entire reason Garland kept him around was to sustain the flow of souls from Gaia to Terra, and that Kuja was doomed to die an early death if Garland doesn't kill him first. Garland explicitly states that he's a stopgap for the next model (Zidane) and nothing more. This is the core of Kuja's [Suicidal Cosmic Temper Tantrum](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuicidalCosmicTemperTantrum).

[Your Soul Is Mine!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YourSoulIsMine): He steals the countless souls stored in [The Invincible](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolAirship) to achieve [Trance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperMode) and gain the power to defeat Garland. Kuja however claims that the souls were more than happy to empower him to get payback against Garland, and let him take them willingly although that's just Kuja's word.

[Ambiguously Human](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguouslyHuman): It's not entirely clear whether Garland is a magical android created by the Terrans, the first Genome, or one of the Terrans themselves. He mentions being "created" to deal with Terra's problems, but Zidane also asks him why he isn't asleep with the rest of the Terrans. That said, even if he is a Terran android or a Genome they created, he most likely shares the Terrans' mentality and outlook on life.
[Ancient Keeper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AncientKeeper): Of Terra's souls and civilization. He's the one watching them and he's been doing it for a loooonngggg time.
[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): He just wants to do what he must to save his civilization. It's just that doing so demands he destroy Gaia.

[The Assimilator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAssimilator): Garland's entire goal is to assimilate the soul-cycle of Gaia to restore Terra and its people, and it's implied that this isn't the first planet he's attacked, either.
[Badass Cape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassCape): Garland's outfit includes a billowing black cape, which whirls dramatically as he moves.
[Bald of Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BaldOfEvil): His beard is his only hair, otherwise he's fully bald. Presumably, that too, is due to his highly advanced age.

[Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad): Garland is one of the few villains who technically crosses the entire spectrum of Big Badness from the real deal to [Big Bad Wannabe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadWannabe). He is introduced as a villainous competitor to Kuja, he turns out to have been his boss and the mastermind behind the events of the entire game and technically the [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad). Then, at the end of the third disc, having made the mistake of focusing all his attention on fighting Zidane and the others, he's blindsided, ousted from power and killed by Kuja.
[The Chessmaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChessmaster): Like Kuja, he's a master strategist; much more impressively, he's behind the plot Kuja was operating in the first and second discs.
[Cool Airship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolAirship): *The Invincible*, which Garland has used to destroy entire cities, and to convert Eidolons.

[Composite Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CompositeCharacter): While Kuja amalgamates the traits of main prominent villains from across the franchise, Garland has taken on the traits of many a [Greater-Scope Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreaterScopeVillain):
    - Like [Zemus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIV), Garland is an alien in charge of a violent [Assimilation Plot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AssimilationPlot) to restore the population of his home planets at the cost of another planet's natives. - Like [Enuo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyV), he is an evil and powerful old sorcerer whose power is contained in a tree of souls. - Like [Emperor Gestahl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVI), Garland is a ruler of a nation that uses the power of espers/eidolons for destruction and conquest and gets killed by his own psychotic underling. - Like [Professor Hojo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVII), Garland is a [Mad Scientist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadScientist) who is responsible for creating both the hero and the main villain.

[Control Freak](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ControlFreak): As the appointed overseer of all Terra, Garland dominates every aspect of his creations' lives, forcing them into a very rigid routine of self-improvement and work in preparation for the time the Genomes can fulfill their purpose as vessels for the souls of Terra, and does not suffer disobedience gladly. In fact, the only reason why Kuja's activities on Gaia were permitted were because most of them benefited Garland in some way - until the battle of Alexandria. Similarly, once Zidane makes it clear that he can't be convinced to become his Angel of Death, Garland rips his soul out, intending to reduce him to another Genome vessel. Very little happens on Terra without Garland's knowledge - to the point that, in a rare moment of emotion at the end of the third disc, he triumphantly proclaims himself the absolute master of all Terra.

[Curb-Stomp Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurbStompBattle): When using *The Invincible*, Garland usually only needs to fire one shot to win a battle. In the Battle of Alexandria, he fired two — the first to kill Alexander, the second to destroy the entire city.
[Dead Person Conversation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadPersonConversation): Returns from the grave to hold one of these in the fourth disc.

[Death Equals Redemption](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathEqualsRedemption): After being killed by Kuja, Garland returns as a spirit to assist Zidane through Memoria. He isn't so much redeemed, as his goals simply line up with Zidane's since he doesn't want to see reality unmade. It's pretty clear he still has no problem with anything he actually did, and really just wishes he had done it *better*.
[Death from Above](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathFromAbove): His modus operandi via *The Invincible* for dealing with troublesome enemies and rebellious pawns is aerial bombardment.
[Defiant to the End](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefiantToTheEnd): With his last breath, Garland coldly informs Kuja that his power is meaningless — and for once, Kuja has nothing to say.

[Disc-One Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneFinalBoss): If it weren't for the existence of a fourth disc, it would've been rather easy to mistake the fight against Garland for the [Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss), or at least one of the final bosses in the game.

[Emperor Scientist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EmperorScientist): He's the de facto King of Terra, and has successfully created an entire species of soulless vessels for the Terrans to inhabit, three soul-bearing operatives to do his bidding, and the Iifa tree.

[Evil Old Folks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilOldFolks): The oldest character of the game is also the most diabolical, though Kuja is his competition. He's planning to systematically destroy Gaia's souls so Terra's souls can take their place.

[Evil Plan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilPlan): This is the true evil plan; the one that starts and guides the conflict. He created Kuja, who, at Garland's behest, encouraged Brahne to pursue her desire for conquest. He gave Kuja the materials to produce magical weaponry, which he would then sell to Brahne — resulting in greater destruction and further casualties in the war across the Mist Continent. He created Zidane, our hero, to ultimately oppose and replace Kuja. All of this was supposed to cause enough death to assimilate Gaia's souls into Terra, so his own civilization could live again.

[Evil Speech Of Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilSpeechOfEvil): In his very first scene (see [Not My Driver](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotMyDriver)), it is made very clear that the new villain is here. It's delivered in grandiose fashion complete with [terrifying musical](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OminousPipeOrgan) [accompaniment.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dAtdSFL89s8) QUOTE "You have gone too far, Kuja. I granted you the freedom to do as you wish in Gaia for one purpose alone. Now that you have lost sight of your mission, I will no longer tolerate your actions. You have not the slightest idea whom you are defying. I will show you soon enough. You too, Zidane..."
[Evil Versus Oblivion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilVersusOblivion): Following his death and Kuja's descent into madness, Garland joined forces with Zidane in order to help him save the universe.

[Evil Virtues](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilVirtues): Dedication and humility. Garland is completely at peace with his purpose as a glorified steward for the Terrans and is calmly uncompromising on his plan to terraform Gaia into a new Terra. After being defeated, [he acknowledges Zidane's strength](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GracefulLoser), and lingers long enough to help save the universe before passing on, [feeling content with how he lived his long life for that one purpose](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IRegretNothing).
[Face Death with Dignity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceDeathWithDignity): In his final words, he explains as much about the Crystal as he can, before calmly bidding farewell to Zidane.
