[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): To Kuja; both are powerful magicians, both make use of cool airships, both make use of the Silver Dragon; both have long-running schemes across the planet; both create living beings for their own mysterious purposes, and both have to deal with those beings becoming sentient and rebellious; both are inhabitants of Terra; both want to take over Gaia. However, where Kuja is a [Large Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam) who likes to behave as flamboyantly as possible, Garland is calm, composed, and rarely acts with any kind of drama; where Kuja is actively cruel and sadistic, Garland is simply pragmatic to the point of ignoring the suffering of others; where Kuja is relentlessly selfish, Garland acts only for the sleeping Terrans and has seemingly no desires of his own; where Kuja refuses to admit defeat even when he has nothing to gain except total destruction, Garland willingly aids Zidane in order to prevent the destruction of the universe.

[Giant Eye of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GiantEyeOfDoom): *The Invincible* sports one of these on its underside as part of its [Wave-Motion Gun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WaveMotionGun), and it usually appears when Garland feels like casting magic on a massive scale.

[Graceful Loser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GracefulLoser): After being defeated, he gracefully acknowledges Zidane's strength. Also, after Kuja murders him and destroys Terra, Garland returns to assist Zidane on his journey through Memoria, even though Zidane's interference made said destruction possible. It's still a sensible move, considering that if Zidane had failed to make his way through Memoria, Kuja would have destroyed the entire universe.

[Greater-Scope Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreaterScopeVillain): He’s responsible for almost everything that has happened in *IX*. He was also responsible for creating both Zidane and Kuja and he was the one who manipulating Queen Brahne and her war.
[High Collar of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HighCollarOfDoom): Garland's collar almost rises over his head; that's the extent of his threat.

[I Regret Nothing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IRegretNothing): Just before his spirit finally passes on, Garland announces that even though he was created with only one purpose in mind, he doesn't regret having lived his life in pursuit of this goal.
[Kamehame Hadoken](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KamehameHadoken): Garland displays this with his Wave attack.

[Long Game](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LongGame): Garland's scheme has been in action for millennia, slowly assimilating the souls of Gaia without anyone ever noticing — up until Kuja got the attention of the heroes.

[Luke, I Am Your Father](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LukeIAmYourFather): Technically speaking. He *did* create Zidane and Kuja after all. Plus, his dialogue indicates that he sees Zidane as something of a son, and not just a weapon — particularly when he's guiding them through Memoria.

[Mind over Matter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindOverMatter): One of his magical specialities is to telekinetically lift an opponent into the air and slam them back into the ground — a spell possessed only by the psychic owl Zemzellett enemies.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): A living reference to the character of the same name from *[Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyI)*. The offhand mention that he once tried "a more direct approach" to things makes it all the more obvious.

[No-Nonsense Nemesis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoNonsenseNemesis): In the event that a threat to his plans is discovered, Garland doesn't bother with scheming, trickery, death-traps, or gloating of any kind; he just has the threat eliminated as quickly as possible. For example, when the summoners of Madain Sari grew too powerful for him to tolerate, Garland carpet-bombed their village into dust; when Kuja tried to take control of the eidolon Alexander, Garland simply assumed control of the *Invincible* and destroyed Alexander with two shots, forcing Kuja into a humiliating defeat; finally, the moment he learned that Zidane would never willingly serve him, Garland just ripped his soul out.

[Not My Driver](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotMyDriver): Garland pulls one of these on Kuja when he tries to summon the *Invincible* during the Battle of Alexandria. Cue massive [Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap) moment as Kuja realises that the airship isn't on autopilot anymore.

[Obviously Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObviouslyEvil): He makes his introduction looking over the destruction of Alexandria, delivers an ominous and threatening monologue as his theme plays an [Ominous Pipe Organ](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OminousPipeOrgan), and wears all black with a cape. It's obvious the moment he appears he's a new villain even if you didn't notice he was named after the main villain from the first game.
[Power Floats](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerFloats): While taking Zidane on a tour of Pandemonium, he casually hovers across the banks of machinery that Zidane has to climb over.
[Pragmatic Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy): He only moves to advance his ultimate goal. Everything else, evil or otherwise, is irrelevant.
[Prophet Eyes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProphetEyes): A brief glimpse of his face during the boss fight shows that Garland has these kind of eyes.
[Psychic Powers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychicPowers): Garland can use telepathy, teleportation and telekinesis.

[Punch-Clock Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunchClockVillain): He takes no pleasure in the chaos and death he’s responsible for. Reviving the Terrans is his primary function, and hijacking Gaea’s life-cycle is the most efficient method to do that.

[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): His general look seems inspired by Darth Vader from *[Star Wars](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/StarWars)*.
    - Functionally, he's similar in respects to FuSoYa from *[Final Fantasy IV](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIV)*, only where FuSoYa's methods in the integration of his kind on another planet are peaceful, Garland's are aggressive. - Fittingly, given how much inspiration *Final Fantasy* takes from *[Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Manga/NausicaaOfTheValleyOfTheWind)*, his scheme and motives are reminiscent of the manga's main antagonist, (SPOILER) the Crypt of Shuwa, a biological program designed by the old humans to purify the Earth from its polluted state. Ultimately, its goal was to cleanse the world, including all the new humans that adapted to it, so that old humanity could be reborn from stasis. Much like Nausicaä's Earth, Terra was a dying world that sought to assimilate Gaia so that its population could be reborn there. In both cases, the old world was wiped out (in this case, by Kuja), but the endings of both stories imply it was already too late to stop the terraforming process.

[Shut Up, Kirk!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShutUpKirk): Close to the end of the third disc, Zidane and the other three members of the group deliver a [Patrick Stewart Speech](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PatrickStewartSpeech) to him; Garland then demands that they put their idealism to the test — and try to lecture him again when they're on the verge of death. He promptly sics the Silver Dragon on the four of them.

[Sliding Scale of Anti-Villains](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlidingScaleOfAntiVillains): The only reason he's antagonistic at all is because he's trying to revive his homeworld. Granted, he doesn't care how many other worlds or people have to die in order to accomplish this.

[Sliding Scale of Villain Threat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlidingScaleOfVillainThreat): A multi-tiered menace, although not to the same extent as Kuja. He starts out as a city level threat in destroying Alexandria; then, when he finally reveals his plan for Terra to assimilate Gaia, he's revealed to be a global threat - though Mikoto implies that he may be a multi-planentary threat. Finally, in his attempts to remove Zidane's soul, he becomes a personal threat.
[Spirit Advisor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpiritAdvisor): After his death, his spirit guides Zidane and company through most of Memoria, although only Zidane can hear him.

[The Stoic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStoic): His dialogue is generally calm and unemotional for most of the game; in fact, it's not until the end of the third disc that we even see him use an exclamation mark in his speech.
[Time Abyss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimeAbyss): Garland's true age is uncertain, but it's known that he's been alive for more than five thousand years.
[Villain Teleportation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainTeleportation): While talking to Zidane, he teleports around the area instead of walking.

[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist): Everything Garland does is ultimately to ensure the restoration of Terra and its people, no matter how many millions of innocent people have to die in order to accomplish this goal. He has no real desires of his own; the only thing he cares about is completing his mission and resurrecting his Terran masters...which arguably makes him as much of a puppet of the Terrans as the black mages and the Genomes.

[You Have Outlived Your Usefulness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveOutlivedYourUsefulness): As soon as you're no longer useful for his plans, Garland will abandon and dispose of you. He even views Zidane as nothing more than a puppet to accomplish his goal, given that he eventually intended for Mikoto to replace Zidane.

tropeName: The AI Is A Cheating Bastard
tropeNotes: [The AI Is A Cheating Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAIIsACheatingBastard): In their second fight, they will cast Virus on the entire party which makes it impossible to earn any experience on them whatsoever. Trying to cure it is pointless as doing so causes them to instantly reapply it. Only rare equipable items will protect you from it. It's implied that their natural form is somehow toxic to life itself.
[Creepy Twins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CreepyTwins): A couple of sinister jester twins. However, as Kuja says, they [aren't actually twins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDividual).
[The Dividual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDividual): They are two halves of the same being.

[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy):
    - Their [Wonder Twin Powers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WonderTwinPowers) are clear homage to Palom and Porom from *[Final Fantasy IV](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIV)*. - They can be considered as incompetent and less insane version of Kefka from *[Final Fantasy VI](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVI)*. They have clown-like appearance, serve an [evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEmperor) [monarch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodSaveUsFromTheQueen), and have clown-ish [leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif). Amusingly, while Kefka's [One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel) form is [more human-like](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BishonenLine), Zorn and Thorn's [One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel) form is monstrous.

[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): They are red and blue jesters whose leitmotif is called "Jesters of the Moon" who eventually fuse together to fight the party. Turns out the reason the planet Gaia has two moons — one red, one blue — is because the red one belonged to the planet Terra and got brought along when the two planets fused together in the distant past.
[Fusion Dance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FusionDance): Technically, it's the inversion of this trope. Zorn and Thorn are two halves of the same being, and the boss Meltigemini is their true form.
[Goldfish Poop Gang](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoldfishPoopGang): They show up at various points in the game to cause trouble for the heroes.

[Happy Harlequin Hat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappyHarlequinHat): They're never seen without their jester caps. Since their true form's heads are shaped like jester hats, they may be wearing them to maintain [The Masquerade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMasquerade).
[Identical Twin ID Tag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IdenticalTwinIDTag): Apart from their respective red and blue outfits, the only way to tell them apart is their expressions and facial makeup.
[Magical Clown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicalClown): They are two jesters who are also wizards and spymasters for Queen Brahne.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName):
    - Zorn is German for anger, and Thorn alludes to suffering; on top of rhyming, these words represent their villainous status quite well. - The French version names them "Pile" and "Face", which can respectively mean "heads" and "tails", referring to the two sides of a coin; fitting, considering they're [The Dividual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDividual). - Meltigemini comes from "gemini", which is Latin for "twins" and "melt" which describes the creature's appearance quite well.

[Mysterious Past](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MysteriousPast): Where did Zorn and Thorn came from? How did they come to work under Queen Brahne? How did they split up from Meltigemini, and for what purpose? All good questions, all never answered.
[Not-So-Harmless Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoHarmlessVillain): It's easy to take them lightly, until they turn into Meltigemini.

[Older Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OlderThanTheyLook): Granted, it's hard to tell because of their thick face makeup, but would you believe that the Ultimania gives their age as being *88*?

[Recurring Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RecurringBoss): Yes, even though the second time they're on the field, Eiko wipes the floor with them; followed by a [Fusion Dance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FusionDance) into their true form of Meltigemini.
[Strange-Syntax Speaker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StrangeSyntaxSpeaker): Like [Yoda](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/StarWars), Thorn speaks.
[Theme Twin Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThemeTwinNaming): Zorn And Thorn.

[Verbal Tic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VerbalTic): The two speak in antimetabole, with Zorn speaking normally and Thorn speaking in reverse order: it's not just an [Identical Twin ID Tag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IdenticalTwinIDTag), it's also a clue that [they're two halves of the same being](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDividual).
[Villainous Harlequin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousHarlequin): Consistent villains that never take off their jester hats.

[Wonder Twin Powers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WonderTwinPowers): Presumably as a [reference](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag) to how Porom and Palom of *[Final Fantasy IV](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIV)* worked together.
[Always Chaotic Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlwaysChaoticEvil): Every one of them is unapologetically evil.

[Ambiguous Gender](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguousGender): Black Waltz 2 has womanly hips and something of a bust, and the robe resembles a [Pimped-Out Dress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PimpedOutDress), but there's no evidence the Black Mages even have genders. Dagger however refers to Black Waltz 2 as a he.
[Artificial Human](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtificialHuman): Like all Black Mages they are artificial constructs.
[Breakout Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakoutCharacter): Black Waltz 3 makes more cameo appearances in spin-off games than the other two.
[The Brute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBrute): Black Waltz 1 is a moderate rank and power mook sent to stomp on his boss's enemies.
[Dual Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualBoss): Black Waltz 1 is fought with Zidane only, but that doesn't stop him from summoning his "pet" to help.
[Elite Mooks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EliteMook): A waltz is much more powerful than a standard mage.
[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart): To Vivi given that their specs are higher than standard mages and they have polar opposite motivations.

[Fire, Ice, Lightning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FireIceLightning): While each is capable of casting multiple elements, each of the Black Mages is more proficient with a different one of these.
    - Black Waltz 1 shows a large affinity with Ice, confronting the party in Ice Cavern, summoning a giant ice creature, and using Blizzard magic for offense and healing. - Black Waltz 2 leans towards Fire, typically casting Fira at fixed portions of the fight despite being proficient with all three elements of -ra magic. - Black Waltz 3 displays a preference for Lightning. In all FMVs he features in, 3 uses Thundara to attack. He also only AOE casts Thundara, having a particular phase of his boss fight dedicated to doing so. Oddly averted after he's broken, where he seems to have respecialized to ice magic, picking up Freeze and ditching Thundara outright.

[Gameplay and Story Integration](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStoryIntegration):
    - Black Waltz 2 will never attack Garnet, since his orders are to *capture* her. If she's the only party member left standing for too long, he will put her to sleep, resulting in a [Non-Standard Game Over](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonStandardGameOver). - Combined with [Logic Bomb](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LogicBomb) in the final encounter with Black Waltz 3; It was told to capture Garnet without harming her, but is stuck in the mindset that it exists only to kill. Thus, when its only opponent left *is* Garnet, Black Waltz 3 begins *beating itself to death* in confusion.
[Good Wings, Evil Wings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodWingsEvilWings): They all have dark blue and black feathered wings.

[Hoist by His Own Petard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HoistByHisOwnPetard): As Black Waltz 3 is chasing the heroes, he charges a Thunder spell to get rid of them. Unfortunately for him, the zaps of energy from the spell make the engine of his ship catch fire, causing it to explode. Despite not having a face, he manages to pull off an excellent [Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap) face when he realizes he screwed himself over.

[Hopeless Boss Fight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HopelessBossFight): Inverted with the second fight against Black Waltz 3. It will never attack Garnet, but unlike Black Waltz 2, rather then putting her to sleep, Black Waltz 3 will just attack itself if the rest of the party is defeated, leading to his own defeat.
[An Ice Person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnIcePerson): Black Waltz 1 uses Blizzard magic to attack and to heal his Sealion summon, which itself is a giant familiar made of ice.

[Implacable Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImplacableMan): Black Waltz 3 could be considered Final Fantasy's equivalent of [the Nemesis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/ResidentEvil3Nemesis). It follows the heroes no matter where they go.

[Improbable Power Discrepancy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobablePowerDiscrepancy): While the Black Waltzes are canonically elite mooks, in battle, their stats are actually *weaker* [than the Black Mage mooks the heroes fight later on](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SortingAlgorithmOfEvil).
[Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog): Black Waltz 3 callously and casually slaughters a group of his fellow Black Mages to get to the party. Vivi was enraged by this.

[Knight of Cerebus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightOfCerebus): The game starts off pretty lighthearted, then Black Waltz 3 slaughters a group of Black Mages trying to protect Vivi. Things just get darker from there.
[Made of Iron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadeOfIron): Black Waltz 3 survives an airship crash and being hit by a tram car, and keeps ticking.

[Madness Mantra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadnessMantra):
QUOTE  **Black Waltz 3:** "I exist only to kill! I exist only to kill! I exist only to kill! I exist only to kill...!"

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): *Waltz*, a three step dance, indicated from the start how many of them there are. This is lampshaded by Zidane when Steiner wonders how many there are.
[Mirror Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MirrorBoss): Black Waltz 2 copies Vivi's spells, taunting him beforehand each time.
[Not Quite Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotQuiteDead): Black Waltz 3 returns one more time in disc 2.
[Obviously Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObviouslyEvil): They look like demons.

[Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap): Black Waltz 3 gives a *beautiful* one in South gate. [It has to be seen to be believed](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jIUfMTtcEjw&t=1m). This is without having voice acting or, yes, a *face*.
[Pimped-Out Dress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PimpedOutDress): Black Waltz 2, which is so long that his feet are never seen.

[Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire): While not as noticeable as the other Black Waltz's elemental preferences, Black Waltz 2's most powerful and common attack is Fira, the first time you see that spell, and the only time for a while.
[Power Floats](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerFloats): Black Waltz 2 never touches the ground until you beat him, of course.
[Psycho Electro](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychoElectro): Black Waltz 3 loves to kill things with lightning.

[Rasputinian Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RasputinianDeath): It takes a lot more than a single boss fight to kill Black Waltz 3. There's also a Cutscene-Max power Trance Vivi blasting him and an airship crashing.
[Robo Speak](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoboSpeak): Black Waltz 3 breaks out the [Madness Mantra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadnessMantra) after his breakdown.

[Rule of Three](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RuleOfThree): Lampshaded after the first fight with No. 3 — when Steiner wonders how many Waltzes there are, Zidane points out that because of [Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName) being in effect, there aren't any more.
[Starter Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StarterVillain): The heroes fight them in disc 1 after escaping the Evil Forest; the first major foes.
[Villainous Breakdown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousBreakdown): Black Waltz 3 goes nuts after the fight with it, repeating "I exist only to kill" over and over as he tries to kill the party.
[Winged Humanoid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WingedHumanoid): All three have black feathered wings.

tropeName: With Great Power Comes Great Insanity
tropeNotes: [With Great Power Comes Great Insanity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WithGreatPowerComesGreatInsanity): It's implied that one of the reasons behind Black Waltz 3's breakdown is that his magical power became too much for him to handle.

[Wouldn't Hit a Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WouldntHitAGirl):
    - Black Waltz 2 will never attack Dagger, since its orders are to *capture* her. However, he will cast Hypnotize on her if she's the only party member left standing, ending the battle in a [Game Over](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameOver). - [Played Straight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayedStraight) with Black Waltz 3, who will attack himself if Garnet is the only party member left standing.
[You Are Number 6](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreNumberSix): In this case, number 1, 2 and 3. They're just artificial people after all. Minor weapons that move.
[Ambiguously Brown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguouslyBrown): It's not clear with ethnicity her dark skin is meant to be from.
[Badasses Wear Bandanas](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassesWearBandanas): She wears a large bandana around her hair when bounty hunting.
[Badass Normal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassNormal): She appears to be a normal human with limited magic and is just really good with an axe.

tropeName: Because You Were Nice to Me
tropeNotes: [Because You Were Nice to Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BecauseYouWereNiceToMe): It's implied that a combination of horror at watching the Alexandrian fleet destroyed and kindness on the part of the Moogles brought about a [Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn).
[Boisterous Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BoisterousBruiser): She wields an axe and is quite happy with combat. Before her name is known, she's even described as 'Boisterous Woman'.
[Chekhov's Gunman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChekhovsGunman): She is mentioned as a contestant in the Festival of the Hunt. You can also read a comment card from her at the Lindblum Hotel.
[Cleavage Window](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CleavageWindow): Her outfit really shows off her breasts and cleavage.
[Companion Cube](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CompanionCube): "My axe is pleased to hear this."

[Enemy Scan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemyScan): Lani is one of the rare enemies in the Final Fantasy series who will use Scan on your party. She changes her tactics after seeing info on a party member she scanned.
[Fiery Redhead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FieryRedhead): She's got red hair and is very enthusiastic about being a bounty hunter, she especially loves combat.

[Gameplay and Story Integration](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStoryIntegration): As she's tasked with bringing Garnet back, that's who she directs all her attacks at in the boss battle. If Garnet is down, she instead focuses on Vivi, since assassinating him is her secondary objective.
[Heel Realization](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelRealization): After Brahne's attack on the Iifa Tree she recognizes how selfish she has been.

[Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Irony): Her written complaint in the Lindblum Hotel guestbook is primarily about how annoying she found the [Save Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SavePoint) moogle in her room to be. She ends up going through a [Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn) because she was rescued by the moogles of Madain Sari.
[Maybe Ever After](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MaybeEverAfter): She appears in the ending sequence attempting to reconcile with Amarant.
[Mini Dress Of Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MiniDressOfPower): Fights in a top and short skirt.
[Ms. Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MsFanservice): With large breasts, cleavage, and bared midriff.
[Not in the Face!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotInTheFace): If you physically attack her, she will snap and scream "what do you think you're doing!"
[Pretty in Mink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrettyInMink): Her skirt is trimmed with white fur.

[Redemption Earns Life](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedemptionEarnsLife): After the end of Disc 2, she gives up on hunting down the party and just sort of hangs out at Madain Sari since there's no money in it for her anymore.

[Villainous BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousBSOD): If the player meets her back at Madain Sari from Disc 3/Part 3 onwards, or while doing the sidequest to learn Dagger's name, without Garnet nor Amarant in the party, she gives a rather big hint that the events at the Iifa Tree [scarred her for life](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DespairEventHorizon).
QUOTE **Lani**: I tried getting back to the Mist Continent, but Fossil Roo was blocked, and the Alexandrian Fleet was destroyed before my eyes. I became so weak after wandering around for days. Then the moogles here rescued me. [That's when I realized I've been so selfish all my life...](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGodWhatHaveIDone)
[Ambiguous Gender](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguousGender): Being what it is, Necron is neither male nor female.

[Anthropomorphic Personification](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnthropomorphicPersonification): It is essentially the living incarnation of the concept of death and despair. Its Japanese name emphasizes it is more an idea than an actual living being.

tropeName: As Long as There Is Evil
tropeNotes: [As Long as There Is Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AsLongAsThereIsEvil): It is an abstract concept; a fundamental part of reality. It's impossible to truly kill it.
[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): Its Japanese name was the Darkness of Eternity. He's called "Darkness" in most others versions.

[Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination): It is a towering statue in the shape of a massive humanoid with strange limbs, otherworldly powers, and dwells in a dimension on the cusp of death.
[Eyes Do Not Belong There](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EyesDoNotBelongThere): Necron has a mask-like face covered in oddly-shaped eye holes.
[Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss): The final challenge of the game.
[Fire, Ice, Lightning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FireIceLightning): Can cast Firaga, Blizzaga, and Thundaga.
[Flaming Meteor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlamingMeteor): Casts Meteor.

[Giant Space Flea from Nowhere](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GiantSpaceFleaFromNowhere): One of the more notable examples in the genre. It doesn't show up until its boss fight at the very end of the game and after being defeated, it is never mentioned during the game's ending. Its main purpose in the game would appear to be thematic rather than direct plot connection.
[Graceful Loser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GracefulLoser): Necron doesn't really mind its defeat. After all, it is eternal.

[Greater-Scope Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreaterScopeVillain): Far more powerful than Kuja or Garland but it sits out the entire game until the end, and is not relevant to the Big Bad's [Evil Plan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilPlan).
[Healing Hands](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HealingHands): Will sometimes heal itself with Curaga.

tropeName: In Your Nature to Destroy Yourselves
tropeNotes: [In Your Nature to Destroy Yourselves](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InYourNatureToDestroyYourselves): It was summoned in response to Kuja's attempts to destroy the Crystal, which served as the origin of all creation. This convinces it that all life ultimately exists for the sole purpose of dying, and that Kuja's actions prove that life desires to return to the "zero world" of nothingness.
[It Is Not Your Time](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItIsNotYourTime): How the battle with him ends, though in a variation on this trope, he needed some convincing through force first.
[Light 'em Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightEmUp): Can cast Holy.

[Living Statue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LivingStatue): It takes the form of a gigantic stone bust of a muscular man with extra appendages. Only its claw-like arms and its wings move though, its central body is inanimate.
[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Considering that "Necro" is part of its name, which is the Greek prefix for death.

[Multiarmed And Dangerous](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultiarmedAndDangerous): Technically. It appears to have two rather ordinary looking arms, plus a second pair which are much larger and more monstrous looking. Except the two ordinary looking arms are not real, they're actually just stone carvings of arms.

[Omnicidal Maniac](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OmnicidalManiac): As Necron itself says, "I exist for one purpose...To return everything back to the zero world, where there is no life and no crystal to give life."

[Signature Move](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SignatureMove): Grand Cross, which can inflict a *huge* number of status effects, including the really nasty ones like zombie, confusion, and petrification. It can also have the potential to reduce the party's HP to the single digits.

[Abusive Parents](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbusiveParents): [Played With](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayedWith). Baku beat Zidane when he was a child, as a punishment for running off in a futile search for his homeland. Zidane seems to hold no ill will towards Baku for it and in fact, he sounds fond of the memory when reciting it to Garnet. It's also heavily implied to be [Anger Born of Worry](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AngerBornOfWorry).
[The Artful Dodger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheArtfulDodger): Blank and Zidane, at the *very* least, are implied to have been cunning thieves in their younger days.
[Artificial Limbs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtificialLimbs): Benero and Zenero's hands are robotic.

[Badasses Wear Bandanas](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassesWearBandanas): Marcus wears a bandana that covers his eyes and can keep up with the party and even braves Evil Forest alone just to free Blank from being petrified.
[Blade Across The Shoulder](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BladeAcrossTheShoulder): Blank does this in his battle stance.
[Blindfolded Vision](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlindfoldedVision): Blank wears a massive strip of thick cloth over his eyes, but still seems to see just fine.
[Boisterous Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BoisterousBruiser): Baku is big and loud, be it fighting or otherwise.

[Bunny-Ears Lawyer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BunnyEarsLawyer): Most of the group, really.
    - Baku's a [Drill Sergeant Nasty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrillSergeantNasty) with a habit of attacking his crew (sometimes as part of unscheduled training sessions, other times because he's in a bad mood), but nobody can doubt his abilities as a leader — after all, he got Tantalus out of Evil Forest alive. Plus he holds back when he fights his crew. - Blank is terrified of Oglops, but he makes up for this phobia through his gifts in fighting, thieving, and potions-brewing. - Cinna is addicted to South Gate Bundt Cake, enjoys playing with dolls, and is insanely protective of his hammer, but he's also a very talented engineer. - Benero and Zenero are both just a tad dimwitted, but they're strong and capable enough to be kept around as [Dumb Muscle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DumbMuscle). - Ruby is hilariously overenthusiastic, easily annoyed, and speaks with an accent unique to the setting, but — as the final scenes display — she's actually a good actor. - Finally, Zidane will flirt with anyone female and of age, but can lie, cheat, steal, and act better than any other member of Tantalus. - Marcus, by comparison, seems pretty normal.

[Butt-Monkey](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButtMonkey): Cinna exists to be humiliated. This is demonstrated in the first battle of the game, where he both deals less damage and takes more; he's useless.
    - Additionally, Steiner swatted Cinna aside as he was chasing Zidane and Garnet/Dagger and Cinna after eating so much South Gate Bundt Cake found himself running away from Baku's Super Tornado Tantalus Punch. Oh, and he was never shown doing any victory poses either in game. Did we mention that Zidane indirectly called Cinna ugly looking and him feeling irritated when being addressed as an uncle by Vivi?
[Cat Folk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CatFolk): Baku and some of the musicians are something like cats. Benero & Zenero resemble the blue tapirs.
[Companion Cube](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CompanionCube): Cinna is very attached to his hammer.
[Cool Ship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolShip): The Prima Vista, is both a ship and a *mobile theater*.
[Covered with Scars](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoveredWithScars): Blank's entire body is a patchwork of stitchmarked scarring.

[The Danza](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDanza): [In-Universe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InUniverse) example; Marcus, Blank, and Zidane go by those names in the play *and* in the game proper. It's possible that Baku named them after the characters in the play (see [The Fagin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFagin) below).

[Duel Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelBoss): Baku fights Zidane one-on-one early in the game, making it one of the first battles fought without even a [Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember) to back him up.

[Easily Forgiven](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EasilyForgiven): Zidane is permanently kicked out of Tantalus in disc 1, but later admits that "it isn't the first time I left." ([We learn more about that in disc 2.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing))
[The Faceless](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFaceless): The Nero families' heads are always covered by their pig masks, and we never get to see what they look like under them.

[The Fagin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFagin): It's heavily implied that Baku is one of these. He is outright stated to have taken in Zidane and raised him to [pickpocket, burgle, and perform classical theater](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArsonMurderAndJaywalking) with the best of them.

[Funetik Aksent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FunetikAksent): All of them sans Blank in the Italian dub. Each has a different one  <sup>note </sup>   Sicilian for Baku, Spanish for Ruby, German for Marcus, Rome Dialect for Cinna, Sardinian for Zenero and Benero   to highlight their nature as a colorful gang of misfits.

[Gentleman Thief](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GentlemanThief): They're classically trained actor theives after all.[Except for Ruby, who is, in fact, a woman.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/PiratesOfTheCaribbean)
[Girly Run](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GirlyRun): Ruby beats out Garnet for the prancing trope.

[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): Blank, Marcus, and Cinna. Marcus serves as one for the longest of the three, being the only one to serve as one beyond Disc 1 as he takes Zidane's place while the party is split so the player can continue to steal items with Garnet's team.
[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice): Blank's assist in the Evil Forest leads him to be petrified. He throws Zidane the map when he realizes he won't get out.
[Hidden Eyes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenEyes): Blank and Marcus, and some of those musicians.

[Homage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Homage):
    - Blank not only has [Black Jack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Manga/BlackJack)'s scars, but even develops a cure for the seed-infection that hits Zidane and some others. - The musicians. Someone at Square obviously watched [that ship movie.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Film/Titanic1997)
[Joke Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JokeCharacter): Cinna has awful stats to the point that even the first tutorial boss can take him out in a single hit.

[Lovable Rogue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LovableRogue): Every mother's son (and daughter) of 'em are a quirky group of [True Companions](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrueCompanions), who are also professional thieves.
[My Hero, Zero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyHeroZero): Blank, in a way. Zero is "empty" which means it is "blank".
[Navel-Deep Neckline](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NavelDeepNeckline): Ruby's top is basically open all the way down to her waist.

[Neighborhood-Friendly Gangsters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeighborhoodFriendlyGangsters): For a gang of thieves, they are on friendly terms with Lindblum's regency, hence why Cid entrusted the task of "kidnapping" Garnet to them. They even help rebuild the Lindblum theater district after the blitz!

[No Name Given](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoNameGiven): The musicians. (The box office guy in Alexandria mentions that Tantalus performs "with accompaniment by Lav Layderce," which could refer to the composer, the conductor, the whole band, anything.)
[Only Sane Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlySaneMan): Marcus, the only member who is not strange in some way.

tropeName: The Pirates Who Don't Do Anything
tropeNotes: [The Pirates Who Don't Do Anything](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePiratesWhoDontDoAnything): Other than the swashbuckling kidnapping attempt that kicks off the game and the performance at the end, Tantalus doesn't really seem to do much in the way of thieving *or* performing. They mostly loiter around various towns and occasionally show up to be useful to their old buddy Zidane. Mostly justified throughout the game, as both personal and global events prevent them from doing their schtick, be it finding a cure for Blank's petrification, to Lindblum getting invaded, to helping repair the city, and accompanying Cid's fleet. The fact that they're back to at least performing at the end signals a return to normalcy in the world.
[Ragtag Bunch of Misfits](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RagtagBunchOfMisfits): They're a group of thieves who also pose as a theatre group and are all a little goofy in some way, Baku in particular.

[Real Men Wear Pink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RealMenWearPink):
    - Pay close attention, Baku has a bright red bow in his hair. - The entire premise of Tantalus (gang of thieves) as a theater group.

[Running Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RunningGag): Baku [sneezing loudly every time he appears](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IncomingHam) and not in the well-known *anime* context of someone talking behind his back, just...so he can sneeze loudly every time he appears.

[Satisfied Street Rat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SatisfiedStreetRat): If any member of Tantalus starts telling you a fascinating sob story about their tragic childhood, stay alert and watch your wallet. These guys make no bones about *loving* their lifestyle.
[Scars are Forever](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScarsAreForever): Blank, and not just on his face. It's a dangerous line of work you know.

[Screw This, I'm Outta Here](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewThisImOuttaHere): Played with. Although Marcus immediately ditches Steiner once they escape the castle rather than go help Garnet, that's because he's prioritizing saving Blank first. Once he's been cured of his pertrifiction Marcus immediately doubles back to the castle with Blank in tow despite Blank being weakened from just being cured telling him to move it because they need to save their buddy's (Zidane) girl. Although they're late to the actual rescue they make it back in time to cover Zidane's escape and, offscreen, manage to recover Steiner, Freya ,and Beatrix and carry them back to Lindblum.
[Shoo the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShooTheDog): Baku turns Zidane away in disc 3 because of his [Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD).

tropeName: So Long, and Thanks for All the Gear
tropeNotes: [So Long, and Thanks for All the Gear](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoLongAndThanksForAllTheGear): All of them technically but while you can't unequip Cinna, and Blank's brief stint in the party is early in the game before you'd have anything particularly rare or useful to put on him, Marcus's turn in Disc 2 can have him potentially have the rare Mythril Sword (which you can buy but is no longer available in shops past a certain point in the game) or even rarer Blood Sword (which is a one of a kind sidequest reward) on him when he leaves the party. You have a brief period to unequip him before he goes, but if you don't know it's coming....

[Southern Belle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SouthernBelle): Ruby affects this in her accent and fashion sense despite there being no equivalent to the American Deep South in this game. Perhaps it's an artistic invention?

[Taken for Granite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakenForGranite): Blank, after saving Zidane from suffering the same fate in the Evil Forest. Fortunately, Marcus and Cinna manage to find a way to return him and only him (as opposed to him and the rest of the forest and its monsters) to normal.

[Talking in Your Sleep](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TalkingInYourSleep): If you examine the Moogle's Flute key item (allows you to summon a save moogle on the world map) in the menu, you get a quotation from a character just like any other key item. In this case, the quotation is from Baku, and reads "Hey, let me touch that red...bonbon-lookin' thing on your head...Zzz..." =Baku sleeptalking=
[Tattooed Crook](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TattooedCrook): Marcus, with [Tron Lines](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TronLines) on his arms, either fancies himself as one or used to be one for real.
[Team Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeamDad): Baku is technically the father of the entire trope, sans blood, because he raised them.

[There Is Another](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThereIsAnother): Played for laughs. Benero and Zenero meet up with a third twin, Genero, in disc 3. Which would, y'know, make them triplets. If you meet them as Zidane, you can challenge them to a [Shell Game](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShellGame) *using themselves*. Just before endgame, on Disc 4, there's a lesser known sidequest involving meeting every single one of their other family and relatives (and there are a lot).
[Tough Love](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ToughLove): Baku will beat you cross-eyed if you try to sass him. Then you'll have a good guffaw together and he'll tell you he likes your spirit.

[True Companions](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrueCompanions): They are very much a foster family. After the Forest of Evil, their main activities are helping Zidane with his save the world business and also researching a cure for Blank's petrification.
[Vanity License Plate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VanityLicensePlate): Variant: the first FMV spends a lot of time around the Prima Vista's seated-mermaid bowsprit.
[Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionGirl): Let's just say she *more* than lives up to her reputation as "a fabled paladin."

[Amazon Brigade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmazonBrigade): Inverted, because she isn't a commander of some small-ish non-gender-standard unit (that honor goes to Steiner). Alexandria is a nation where women are dominant, and thus Beatrix is the general of her all-female army.

[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): She's a dutiful general who serves her kingdom and her queen. Too bad that her queen has become a greedy conqueror...Beatrix leads the Alexandrian army during the invasions of Burmecia and Cleyra, but acts like a general invading another kingdom would. She doesn't revel in pointless acts of villainy and becomes unnerved after witnessing Brahne destroy Cleyra with an Eidolon even though the city was already defeated. Unsurprisingly, she pulls a [Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn) after she realizes that her queen has gone too far.

[Badass Boast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBoast): More than one and every time, it also counts as a [Pre-Asskicking One-Liner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PreAsskickingOneLiner).
QUOTE "I once killed a hundred knights single-handedly. To me, you two are nothing more than insects."

QUOTE "Let me shatter your delusions of grandeur."
[Battle Couple](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleCouple): With her fellow military commander Steiner in disc 3 after Love Letter Lunacy drew them together.
[Belligerent Sexual Tension](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BelligerentSexualTension): She and Steiner ultimately ended up together depite their initially antagonistic relationship.
[Combat Medic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatMedic): She's a dreaded swordfighter, but can also use healing spells.

[Dark and Troubled Past](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkAndTroubledPast): Downplayed. Supplementary material states that back in the day, Steiner and her got along well until one of their sparring matches got out of hand. At that time, they were more or less equal in strength but Steiner accidentally hit her in the face, destroying her eye. It's implied that Steiner never really apologized for it because of his lack of social skills. As time went on, Beatrix grew much stronger than him and became a general while his underappreciated Knights of Pluto became a laughingstock. He grew unfathomably jealous and she never really forgave him for her eye. When they eventually wonder if they have feelings for each other, they are both flabbergasted and confused about how much they really care about each other.
[Disc-One Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneFinalBoss): Literally; the first fight against her concludes the game's first disc.
[Distaff Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DistaffCounterpart): To Steiner, in many ways; commander, honorbond, conflicted loyalties, sword using etc.

[The Dreaded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDreaded): The [terrified reaction](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap) of the Burmecian soldier who wanted to avenge his town is a good testimony of what her name means. Just finding out his enemy would be Beatrix was enough to stop the soldier in his tracks.

[Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards): Upon finding out about the Queen's true evil nature and that she was merely used as her puppet all this time, she starts to have second thoughts about what she's done. She also objects to Brahne using the Black Mages in battle and blowing up Cleyra with Odin, insisting that the army was enough, and completely destroying Cleyra wasn't necessary.
[Eyepatch of Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EyepatchOfPower): The loss of her eye marks her as *dangerous* not disabled.

[Flower Motifs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlowerMotifs): [Something about a Rose](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SomethingAboutARose) — her leitmotif is "Rose of May," and there is a rose emblem emblazoned on the back of her uniform (though it's hard to notice because of her hair).

[Gameplay and Story Integration](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStoryIntegration): Is known as the best warrior on the planet and [boy does she back it up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InvincibleVillain).
[Gratuitous Japanese](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GratuitousJapanese): Has the special command "Seiken" (Holy Sword) in a game that otherwise lacks much Japanese flavoring.
[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): Helping Garnet escape the castle, and again when the mist monsters attack Alexandria.
[Handicapped Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HandicappedBadass): She is Alexandria's best warrior despite the loss of her right eye.

tropeName: Heads I Win, Tails You Lose
tropeNotes: [Heads I Win, Tails You Lose](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeadsIWinTailsYouLose): It's impossible to truly beat her. Whenever her HP drops below a certain point, she'll activate one of her Seiken powers and knock your entire party's HP down to 1, ending the battle.
[Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn): Turns against the evil queen to help the heroes, after it's confirmed the queen tried to execute Garnet.

[Heel Realization](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelRealization): When the Queen orders her to kill Garnet, she realizes that the queen truly is as evil as she feared. Shortly before this, after Cleyra's destruction, Beatrix wonders if she has a will of her own.
[Holy Hand Grenade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HolyHandGrenade): Can use the powerful Holy spell once she's a temporary party member.
[Hopeless Boss Fight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HopelessBossFight): Every battle against her cannot be won.

[I Gave My Word](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IGaveMyWord): Her oath to protect Princess Garnet eventually helps prompt her [Heel Realization](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelRealization) and [Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn).

[Invincible Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InvincibleVillain): Before deciding to join Zidane's party in protecting Garnet, she was this for much of the game, considering she was still working for the blatantly evil queen and impossible to defeat during each encounter.
[Jiggle Physics](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JigglePhysics): The PC version added a little bounce to her bosom whenever she claps her fist over her chest.
[The Juggernaut](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheJuggernaut): She is a [One-Woman Army](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWomanArmy) that no number of knights, or the entire heroic party, can stop.

[Karma Houdini](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmaHoudini): [Downplayed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DownplayedTrope). Considering that she partook in the destructions of both Burmecia and Cleyra out of loyalty to Queen Brahne, she gets off rather lightly. However, those destructions were caused by the Black Mages and Brahne's eidolons, not by Beatrix or her soldiers. She is also genuinely sincere in her desire to repent for what she did in Brahne's service and even apologizes to Freya for her actions. Plus, agreeing to fight alongside Freya and Steiner against Zorn and Thorn's Bandersnatches results in Beatrix's first major *defeat* in the entire game, to the point that Blank reports that she was actually knocked unconscious and had to be rescued.

[Knight in Shining Armor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightInShiningArmor): She always believed herself to be a heroic and loyal knight. She simply doesn't realize that she's not on the heroic side at first.
[Lady of War](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyOfWar): She's a feminine gentlewoman who uses her sword with impeccable grace and poise as a renown warrior.
[Lawful Stupid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LawfulStupid): Initially, much like Steiner, she has "obey my queen" above "don't commit genocide." She gets over it a lot quicker than he does.

[Magic Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicKnight): She mostly uses sword techniques during fights, but her brief moments as a [Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember) show she also knows a few spells of White Magic.

[Mama Bear](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MamaBear): To Garnet. When the Queen orders Garnet's execution, Beatrix goes so far as to change sides. Even after Garnet becomes Queen, Beatrix acts as her primary adviser and rules the nation in her stead while Garnet hunts down Kuja.

[My Country, Right or Wrong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyCountryRightOrWrong): Shares this dilemma with Steiner. Like Steiner, she eventually [realizes what Brahne has become](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodSaveUsFromTheQueen) and shifts loyalty to her daughter.

tropeName: My God, What Have I Done?
tropeNotes: [My God, What Have I Done?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGodWhatHaveIDone): Shares this sentiment once she actually sees Garnet was put under a sleeping spell, confirming the Queen's actions to have her executed. Beatrix also realizes that her attacks against Burmecia and Cleyra were in the wrong and could have been prevented if she had questioned Brahne sooner.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): Shares a lot in common with [Cecil Harvey](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIV) and is likely a nod to the character. Like with Cecil, she is a paladin and swears to protect those she holds dear. She follows orders from the Queen without question and then starts to doubt her once she sees how genocidal she has become. After her [Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn), she does everything she can to make amends for her actions.
[Noble Top Enforcer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NobleTopEnforcer): Her official job description is "Protect the Queen"; what she usually does goes way beyond it.
[Not So Stoic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoStoic): Quite the romantic, especially when it comes to love letters.

[Older Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OlderThanTheyLook): Perhaps it's because the in-game sprite, but you are forgiven if you mistake her to be around the same age as Zidane or just a bit older, either in her late teens or early 20s. But she's actually 27 years old (and 28 during the ending).
[The Paladin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePaladin): In true *Final Fantasy* tradition. She combines sword skills with white magic, and goes through a redemption arc in the course of the game.

[Parental Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalSubstitute): Alongside Steiner after Brahne is killed, as she's the gentle and calm maternal figure to the newly crowned Garnet who also acts as regent while the queen is off hunting Kuja.
[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): Her love and protective attitude towards Princess Garnet and Alexandria.

[Promoted to Playable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PromotedToPlayable): Beatrix was an NPC in the original game but becomes playable in other spinoffs such as *[Dissidia Final Fantasy: Opera Omnia](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/DissidiaFinalFantasyOperaOmnia)*, *[Final Fantasy Brave Exvius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyBraveExvius)* and *[Final Fantasy Record Keeper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyRecordKeeper)*.

[Pyrrhic Victory](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PyrrhicVictory): Her third win against Zidane and friends very nearly ends up as this; having defeated them as soundly as ever, she realizes almost too late that they were trying to rescue Princess Garnet, and has to use her powers to heal her and awaken her from the magically-induced coma - only *just* succeeding. Had the battle carried on any longer (for example, if Beatrix decided to finish Zidane and the others off), Garnet might have been beyond saving by the time Beatrix noticed her.
[Recurring Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RecurringBoss): Fought three times as a boss, none of which can be won.

[Redemption Demotion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedemptionDemotion): Mostly downplayed. She doesn't have nearly as much HP as a guest party member compared to when you fight her, but she is still monstrously powerful. The same Shock ability that she can use to one-shot your party at level twenty or so (with nearly a thousand damage) will *also* one-shot the first enemy she fights when she's an ally (where it will do about 1900 damage).

[Sarcastic Devotee](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SarcasticDevotee): The first sign that her loyalty is starting to falter arrives when she quite bitterly notices that the Queen shows her no gratitude for retrieving the Gem from Cleyra and favors the Black Mages and Eidolons over her number one general.

[Timed Mission](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimedMission): She always has two good equipment pieces to steal; the catch is getting them before she decides to deal out a [Total Party Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TotalPartyKill) to end the battle.
[To Be Lawful or Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ToBeLawfulOrGood): Like Steiner, her dilemma is her moral code vs her oath of fealty. It also has the same solution: heroic princess > evil queen.

[White Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMagic): Has several white magic spells when she's a temporary party member and can also be seen using it to revive Garnet from the sleeping spell that Zorn and Thorn used on her.

[World's Best Warrior](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorldsBestWarrior): When Beatrix is properly introduced in Burmecia, Freya remembers a conversation with Fratley in which he refers to Beatrix as the world's greatest swordswoman, with legends of her killing hundreds of soldiers all on her own. As her boss fights show, she's earned the reputation.
[Worthy Opponent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent): She's looking for one. In the end, she may not have had one after all.

[Almighty Janitor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlmightyJanitor): an [Invoked Trope](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InvokedTrope). He's the current Tetra Master champion, but due to being an oglop at the time of the tournament in Treno, he has to ask an NPC to play for him (while giving her instructions), making the crowd label *her* as the champ, and he has to pose as her "pet", much to Cid's dismay.
[Badass Cape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassCape): So badass it stays with him through two [transformations](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForcedTransformation) (see below).
[Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood): A textbook example. The party takes out Kuja, but they wouldn't get anywhere without Cid's backing.
[Cool Airship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolAirship): Cid's prototype steam-powered airships usually fall under this heading — with the possible exception of the Hilda Garde II.
[Cool Chair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolChair): His throne has a built-in elevator that allows the throne itself to move between two floors.
[Cool Old Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolOldGuy): An older man, a technological genius, helps out the party in a myriad of ways and is just a good guy overall.
[Emperor Scientist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EmperorScientist): The monarch of Lindblum is busy developing a groundbreaking new model of airship.

[Forced Transformation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForcedTransformation): Transformed into an oglop (by his wife Hilda), and later, after an unsuccessful attempt for a cure, a frog. Doesn't stop him from ruling his country, though.

[Gadgeteer Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GadgeteerGenius): A trait common with most Cids of *[Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/FinalFantasy)*. So, not surprising at all. Part of the plot involves getting him back into human form, because being an oglop, and later a frog, messes with his mind and keeps him from exercising his full potential as an airship engineer/designer.
[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): At one point you have to control him in a dungeon, but he won't fight in battle.
[Honorary Uncle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HonoraryUncle): Treated Dagger like family, she even calls him Uncle Cid.
[King of Games](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KingOfGames): He's the champion of Tetra Master.

[Literal Transformative Experience](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LiteralTransformativeExperience): in Disc 3, Cid is finally reunited with his wife, forgiven for his infidelity and transformed back into a human; not only is Cid able to return to work with renewed confidence and design the [Cool Airship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolAirship) of the game, but he enjoys a much better relationship with Hilda from then on.

tropeName: The Mind Is a Plaything of the Body
tropeNotes: [The Mind Is a Plaything of the Body](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMindIsAPlaythingOfTheBody): As a human, he's one of the most brilliant scientists in the world. In his oglop and frog forms, his mental faculties aren't nearly as sharp, which prevents him from finishing an advanced airship to help the heroes until his cursed is reversed.
[Morphic Resonance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MorphicResonance): His mustache is always with him through both transformations.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag):
    - He's the 9th Cid (including Cidolfus Orlandeau from Final Fantasy Tactics.) - Fabul... [What kingdom do we know by that name?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIV)
[Non-Mammalian Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonMammalianHair): His mustache stays no matter what he's [polymorphed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForcedTransformation) into.
[Parental Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalSubstitute): Eventually adopts Eiko. He is very pleased to hear her call him father.
[Really Gets Around](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReallyGetsAround): It's hinted that he was always a womanizer, and that his wife only found out about *one* of his mistresses.
[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): "a peaceful but proactive ruler". He provides regular support for the heroes.

[Royals Who Actually Do Something](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalsWhoActuallyDoSomething): He accompanies Zidane and company for part of their journey, and he also designs the airship they travel on later in the game. In fact, he rescues half of the party from a deathtrap during their imprisonment in Kuja's desert castle, personally. While still in frog-form. Later on, he helps lead the armada of airships — almost all of which he designed and his country built — against the horde of silver dragons that Kuja sent after the party en route to the final dungeon.
[Silver Fox](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SilverFox): His mustache is grey, but he can still charm the ladies.
[Verbal Tic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VerbalTic): "Gwok" as an oglop, "Ribbit" as a frog. Ever after he's transformed back to his old self, he has a bit of trouble dropping them.
[Worf Had the Flu](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorfHadTheFlu): Being turned into an oglop then later as a frog seriously hampers his ship-making abilities.
[Younger Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YoungerThanTheyLook): He is 35.
[Absent-Minded Professor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbsentMindedProfessor): Tends to get lost in thought rather easily, wandering off muttering to himself about whatever's currently on his mind.
[Accidental Misnaming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AccidentalMisnaming): Baku can't get his name right.
[Eccentric Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EccentricMentor): Tot's a smart guy, but get him started on a subject that interests him, and he'll fly off into his own little world.
[Gag Nose](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GagNose): One so large that it accounts for roughly 75% of the total size of his head.
[Intergenerational Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IntergenerationalFriendship): with Eiko whom he helps write a love letter.
[The Last DJ](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLastDJ): Chose to leave Alexandria when Kuja started influencing Brahne's rule.
[Miniature Senior Citizens](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MiniatureSeniorCitizens): That hat makes up a quarter of his height.
[Mr. Exposition](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrExposition): He provides a lot of information on the backstory of the setting and some of the characters, including the truth behind Garnet's adoption.

[Omnidisciplinary Scientist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OmnidisciplinaryScientist): Dr. Tot tutored a young Garnet, and is also an accomplished writer, historian, and astronomer. He also apparently has some medical training, given that he mixed a potion that was meant to cure Cid of his being turned into an oglop. In fact, all it did was turn him into a frog, but in Dr. Tot's defense, he wasn't sure if the remedy was going to work anyway.
[Opaque Nerd Glasses](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OpaqueNerdGlasses): Eiko says they mark him as a nerdy philosopher, which he is.

[Parental Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalSubstitute): Dr. Tot provides both emotional support and material aid to Garnet during Discs 2 and 3. He also helps Eiko write a love letter to Zidane.
[The Artful Dodger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheArtfulDodger): Introduced running around Alexandria, "accidentally" bumping into people.
[Bratty Half-Pint](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrattyHalfPint): The kid sure has an attitude, that's for sure.

[Chekhov's Gunman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChekhovsGunman): He first appears at the beginning of the game in Alexandria, helping Vivi sneak inside the theater to watch *I Want to be Your Canary* in secret. He doesn't reappear until much later in the game, when he's revealed as the prince of Burmecia.

[Keet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Keet): Seeing him run around and act high and mighty is quite a sight and especially since he hangs around [Shrinking Violet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShrinkingViolet) Vivi so much.

[Rebel Prince](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RebelPrince): Has no desire to return to his homeland, even before it's destroyed. After the war, he can be seen running helter skelter through the streets of Alexandria with nary a care.
[Running Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RunningGag): Runs over Vivi every time he shows up.

[Walking the Earth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingTheEarth): Puck travels all over the world and through his travels, he encounters Sir Fratley and then continues his travels after sending him to Cleyra to help out.
[Big Damn Heroes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigDamnHeroes): His return to Cleyra is marked by him saving people from black mages.

[Laser-Guided Amnesia](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaserGuidedAmnesia): He remembers nothing about Freya, or himself. He just feels compelled to fight [For Great Justice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForGreatJustice).
[One True Love](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneTrueLove): He never does remember his past or Freya, but by the end of the game, he's fallen in love with her all over again.
[Punny Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunnyName): Sir F**rat**ley.
[Artificial Human](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtificialHuman): Like her whole race she was created by Garland.

[Cain and Abel and Seth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CainAndAbelAndSeth): The third Angel of Death. Mikoto provides important exposition but otherwise receives less focus than her brothers and is largely an outside observer to their conflict.
[Defrosting Ice Queen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefrostingIceQueen): Scenes of her in the Black Mage Village show that she is slowly learning about concepts like friendship and love.

[Emotionless Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EmotionlessGirl): She was given a soul by Garland, and therefore she's *capable* of emotions, but because she grew up exclusively around other Genomes, she has no clue how to use them.

[Happily Adopted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappilyAdopted): By Zidane as his sister and by the Black Mages as their friend. Mikoto and the rest of the Genomes find a home in the Black Mage Village, learning about the ways of Gaia and that there is more to life than waiting in an emotionless fog.
[Ms. Exposition](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MsExposition): Her initial role when the gang first arrives in Bran Bal is explaining how things work there.
[Mysterious Waif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MysteriousWaif): First appears as an enigmatic, silent girl whom Zidane feels compelled to follow.
[Scary Dogmatic Aliens](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScaryDogmaticAliens): She is a Terran. She's truthful, but her quietness and lack of emotion make her appear cold.

[Sugar-and-Ice Personality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SugarAndIcePersonality): Mixed with a bit of [Tsundere](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Tsundere): she seems as cold and remote as the other Genomes, but grows flustered and indignant when Zidane refers to her as his little sister, and later waxes compassionately about Kuja and his impact on the Genomes.

[Younger Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YoungerThanTheyLook): She's an [Artificial Human](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtificialHuman) created by Garland, but she appears as a teenage girl of around 15 years old.
[Badasses Wear Bandanas](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassesWearBandanas): As a proper world-traveling adventurer, he wears a bandana.
[Bold Explorer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BoldExplorer): His main claim to fame is his wide ranging exploration.
[Famed In-Story](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FamedInStory): Among the Moogles; they all seem to know who he is, and for them a visit from Stiltzkin is something to write a letter to your friends about.
[Perpetual Poverty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PerpetualPoverty): Hinted at; he'll offer you items for a price to fund his trip.
[Recurring Traveller](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RecurringTraveller): He pops up at the same locations as the heroes, if they can find him.
[Walking the Earth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingTheEarth): Backpacking from one end of Gaia to the other.

[Dirty Coward](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyCoward): Whenever confronted by someone who looks capable of fighting, he immediately runs away in fear. This usually results in him dropping some item for the party in the process.
[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): His multiple arms are a rather subtle example, given his true identity.
[I Have Many Names](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IHaveManyNames): His real name is Gilgamesh. Yes, **[that Gilgamesh](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LivingLegend)**.

[Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog): He shamelessly pickpockets the player on multiple occasions.
    - When he first appears, going without speaking to him will result in him suddenly and violently mugging Vivi before running off. - When Garnet first arrives in Treno, Jack will bump into her and rob her if the appropriate ATE is viewed. - Finally, if the player takes more than twelve hours to finish the game, he will steal the Excalibur II, Steiner's Ultimate Weapon, from Memoria.

[Leeroy Jenkins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeeroyJenkins): His tough-guy act is a response to his being bullied for having four arms. But an act is all it is — he [nearly craps himself with fear](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap) when he realizes that he's trying to pick a fight with Amarant. Steiner and Quina, the comic relief characters, also intimidate him at different points during the game.
[Multi-Armed and Dangerous](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultiArmedAndDangerous): Minus the dangerous part but definitely the arms. He's Gilgamesh after all.
[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): A walking one considering that he's Gilgamesh.
[Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap): Nearly soils himself with fear when he realizes that he's trying to pick a fight with Amarant.
[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): He provides your first Tetra Master tutorial, and thus showing that he's not all bad.
[Recurring Traveller](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RecurringTraveller): The heroes can find him in many locations.
[Walking the Earth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingTheEarth): He travels the world and is encountered in Alexandria and later Daguerreo and then leaves after his sidequest is over.
[Would Hurt a Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WouldHurtAChild): Perhaps not *"hurt"*, but he's not above mugging Vivi or attempting to kidnap Eiko to get back at Amarant.

[Affectionate Nickname](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffectionateNickname): After she turns Cid back into a human, she is quite affectionate with him and is shown to have several pet names for him, variously calling him "sugar-cup," "darling" and "my sweet froggy-woggy" (referential of the fact that he was also a frog for a while due to a potion.)
[Gilded Cage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GildedCage): Says that Kuja didn't treat her like a prisoner and was very nice to her.
[I Call Her "Vera"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ICallHerVera): The Hilda Garde airships were of course named after her.
[Lady of Black Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyOfBlackMagic): Has some magic though the extent of it is unknown.
[Ms. Exposition](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MsExposition): Midway through Disk 3, having the benefit of Kuja explaining his entire plan to her while she was held prisoner.
[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): She shares her name as Princess Hilda from *Final Fantasy II*.
[Pimped-Out Dress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PimpedOutDress): Complete with hoopskirts, bustle, poofy sleeves and a train.

["Shaggy Dog" Story](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShaggyDogStory): Is simply found by accident in Mt Gulug where Kuja abandoned her and needs little persuasion to turn Cid back into a human. Therefore, all the trouble to change him back without her help was pointless.
[The Unfair Sex](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfairSex): Averted. Cid calls her out on her petty revenge and the two admit how silly they've both been before reconciling.
[Woman Scorned](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WomanScorned): Turned Cid into an oglop as revenge for him cheating on her with a waitress.

[Bad Liar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadLiar): Insists he doesn't know anyone by the name of Quan, but repeatedly makes it clear he knows Quan is of the Qu tribe and has enough familiarity with him to call him a bigot on principle.
[Chef of Iron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChefOfIron): As Quina's master, he is highly skilled in the art of culinary combat.

[Improbable Weapon User](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobableWeaponUser): As with all Qus, Quale uses a giant dinner fork as a weapon. He also has a giant sword-like carving knife hanging on the wall of his house in the Qu's Marsh on the Mist Continent.
[Making a Splash](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MakingASplash): Uses the Water and Aqua Breath spells a lot, and is healed by Water-elemental attacks.
[Optional Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalBoss): Fighting him is optional, but he gives the best weapon for Quina if he is defeated.
[Rolling Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RollingAttack): Rolling Attack, where he curls into a ball and launches himself at a party member.
[Status Effects](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatusEffects): Will inflict Poison, Mini, Confuse, Blind, and Silence.

[Stern Teacher](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SternTeacher): Quale initially reproaches Quina for not being able to feed himself and needing Zidane to catch a frog for him. However, once Quina buckles down and starts applying himself to catching frogs, Quale begins rewarding his progress. Later, Quale challenges Quina to a final test once s/he catches 99 frogs, and congratulates Quina on his progress when s/he wins.
[Supreme Chef](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SupremeChef): He's a master Gourmand.
[Suspiciously Specific Denial](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuspiciouslySpecificDenial): Claims to "not know that bigot" when Vivi asks about Quan.
[Load-Bearing Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoadBearingBoss): After its death, Evil Forest turns to stone.
[Man-Eating Plant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManEatingPlant): A plant with flower petals on its head that plans to eat the princess.
[Starter Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StarterVillain): Other than the Black Waltzes, it is the first 'wild monster' boss that the party faced.

[Wake-Up Call Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WakeUpCallBoss): In a meta sense. Those familiar with previous games will find this guy *much* nastier than [Guard Scorpion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Videogame/FinalFantasyVII) and [Ifrit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVIII).

[Alas, Poor Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlasPoorVillain): All we know him as is a puppet of Zorn and Thorn, the Burmecians are mortified though, assuring us normally he is a stoic noble guardian. He doesn’t get better, he’s killed without ceremony
[Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy): He’s being controlled by Zorn and Thorn.
[Making a Splash](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MakingASplash): He often uses "Water".
[Non-Malicious Monster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonMaliciousMonster): Before Zorn and Thorn took control of him he was a fully sentient friendly guardian monster of Burmecia.

[Wake-Up Call Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WakeUpCallBoss): He's a pretty damn tough guy for the point you encounter him in-game, especially if you're underleveled. He'll also constantly inflict Vivi with Silence so that he can't use his magic on him.

[Weaksauce Weakness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeaksauceWeakness): Throwing a Tent (which applies blind/silence/poison) will absolutely cripple him. Players who [somehow find this out by accident](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuideDangIt) will later get a lot more mileage out of this little trick.

[Badass Boast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBoast): Claims the party cannot defeat him as he has "seen the end of his thousand-year life, and it is not now." [Cue the party destroying him minutes later.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenreBlind)

[Boss-Altering Consequence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossAlteringConsequence): Being undead, it can be defeated instantaneously with a Phoenix Down, Life spell, or an Elixir. However, using a Fire attack on it will raise its strength, and allow it to use an ability called Fire Blades.
[Cannot Tell a Lie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CannotTellALie): It's not that he's a [Bad Liar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadLiar); he *literally* cannot lie, as he admits himself.

[Climax Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClimaxBoss): Defeating him stops the Mist. Were it not for the ongoing threat of Kuja, he could arguably be considered a [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) in his own right given the Mist's effect on the world.
[Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination): Soulcage's plant design looks more alien, granted as he and the Iifa Tree are of Terra origin.

[Kill It with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KillItWithFire): Zig-zagged. It has an elemental weakness to Fire magic, but it'll prompt Soulcage to use Fire Blades at the party, making his attacks deadlier until the flames are extinguished by using ice/water-related attacks on him, or never using a fire-related attack on him in the first place.

[Logical Weakness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LogicalWeakness): Being an undead tree, his weakness to fire makes sense. Unfortunately, it also makes sense that lighting him on fire will allow him to deal fire-elemental damage of his own, increasing its attack potential.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): His name's meaning is not immediately apparent until Garland's plan is understood. Soulcage is reponsible for filtering the souls of Gaia so that Terran souls can take their place.

[Revive Kills Zombie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReviveKillsZombie): He's a damn tough guy if you decide to fight him fair and square, but you could alternatively get the fight over in a flash with Phoenix Downs or Elixirs.
