[The Undead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUndead): It is [a zombie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurZombiesAreDifferent) that looks like a giant tree.

[Weaksauce Weakness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeaksauceWeakness): Due to being undead, Soulcage can be instantly killed through the Life spell or Elixir item, can or reduced to single digit HP with a Phoenix Down.
[When Trees Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhenTreesAttack): A sapient [zombie-tree-monster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NinjaPirateZombieRobot) who attacks the party.
[Casting a Shadow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastingAShadow): Its signature attack "Eternal Darkness" deals Dark-elemental damage.
[Cool Ship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolShip): It looks like a pretty badass airship.
[Death from Above](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathFromAbove): The Eidolon.

[Defeat Means Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefeatMeansFriendship): Subverted. The fact that you can summon it has nothing to do with its defeat in Oeilvert. It's not even certain whether the Ark you fight as a boss and the Ark you summon are the same entity.
[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): Its original attack name is "Dark Fate".
[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): It's based on the player-controlled mech from the old Squaresoft game Cruise Chaser Blassty, but with more of a fantasy flair to it.
[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): Basically a Dark-elemental airship version of Alexander, a Holy-elemental castle. Both can transform.

[Kill It with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KillItWithFire): When it first attacks, all of its firepower does this to the point it evokes "[War Is Hell](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WarIsHell)" and a plain glimpse into hell. No wonder why it's considered Shadow elemental. Then...

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): You need the Pumice in order to learn how to summon Ark. In the Japanese version, Pumice is simply called a Floating Stone, which was also an item required to receive the airship in *[Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyI)*.
[Nuke 'em](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NukeEm): Its send-off is an ultra powered laser blast so powerful, you can see the blast from space.
[Sapient Ship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SapientShip): An eidolon shaped like an airship.

[Transforming Mecha](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TransformingMecha): When summoned, it turns from its airship form to a badass mecha form, then lets out tons of lasers on the enemies. Fortunately, it never transforms when you fight it as a boss.

[Achilles' Heel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AchillesHeel): All of its attacks are considered magical and can be reflected. If Eiko is in the party her Carbuncle summon can render the entire party invulnerable against Valia Pira's attacks for multiple turns, and if at least one party member has Auto-Reflect equipped, the battle becomes outright [impossible to lose](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ZeroEffortBoss).

[Attack Reflector](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AttackReflector): Occasionally casts Reflect on itself, which can be annoying considering the Desert Palace party is likely to consist of primarily spellcasters, thanks to Oeilvert's [Anti-Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiMagic) properties.

[Boss-Altering Consequence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossAlteringConsequence): At the start of the battle, it gains a number of buffs dependent on the bloodstones the player failed to deactivate while exploring the Desert Palace. However, it *also* gains those buffs if anyone in the party happens to be wearing any of the equipment dropped from the deactivated bloodstones. As a result, it can become anything from a virtual [Zero-Effort Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ZeroEffortBoss) to one of the most challenging fights in the game depending on the player's actions.
[Fire, Ice, Lightning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FireIceLightning): Primarily attacks with the -aga level variants of the three primary [Black Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMagic) spells.

[Giant Space Flea from Nowhere](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GiantSpaceFleaFromNowhere): Exists exclusively to provide a boss fight for the Desert Palace. Kuja never mentions its existence, and it plays no role in the plot before or after the battle against it.

[Guide Dang It!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuideDangIt): None of the details under [Puzzle Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PuzzleBoss) below are spelled out to the player prior to the boss fight prior. Hope you saved beforehand (and/or looked up a strategy guide) if you happened to mess up.
[Holy Hand Grenade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HolyHandGrenade): Should the fight drag on too long, it'll start pulling out Holy and Flare spells in favor of its basic attacks.

[Status Effects](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatusEffects): Can use Freeze (which makes the next physical attack that connects a [One-Hit Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill)) and Mustard Bomb (which will cause the target to die if they take any action, even an automatic counterattack due to being hit, or simply defending). What can make this frustrating is if the player doesn't have Eiko in the party, or if she hasn't learned Esuna yet, then there is no way to remove these effects unless the target is killed.
[Blow You Away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlowYouAway): Tiamat has the ability to blow a party member away from battle.
[Combat Tentacles](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatTentacles): Unsurprisingly, Kraken has these.
[Elemental Embodiment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElementalEmbodiment): Each Chaos Guardian represents a different elemental power. Lich is earth, Kraken is water, Marilis is fire, and Tiamat is wind.
[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): Series veterans will recognize them as the Four Fiends from *[Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyI)*.
[Four Is Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourIsDeath): There's four of them, and they are quite deadly indeed.

[Giant Space Flea from Nowhere](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GiantSpaceFleaFromNowhere): Their origins are not really explained, although if they are the "four tremendous sacrifices" and the "selected subjects" mentioned in Oeilvert, they may be implied to be Terran warriors who agreed to be turned into monsters in order to safeguard the Shrines.
[Multi-Armed and Dangerous](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultiArmedAndDangerous): Marilis is wielding swords in her revived self.
[Multiple Head Case](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultipleHeadCase): Tiamat has three heads.

[One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel): All of the Guardians of Terra come back in altered forms, usually with more limbs or heads. Marilis initially has two arms at the Fire Shrine, but later has six in Memoria; Tiamat only has one head at the Wind Shrine, but three heads in Memoria; Kraken has only a few tentacles at the Water Shrine(although he doesn't appear on screen-this image only comes from one of the artbooks) but has two much larger tentacles in Memoria; and Lich has short blades on his arms, but comes back with [Spikes of Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpikesOfVillainy), including long [BFS-sized](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS) blades on his arms, in Memoria.
[Our Dragons Are Different](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurDragonsAreDifferent): Tiamat is a dragon.
[Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire): Marilis uses fire as her magic power.
[Skeletons In Thecoat Closet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkeletonsInThecoatCloset): Lich wears a necklace made of skulls and armor made out of bones.
[Snake People](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SnakePeople): Marilis's appearance is half-serpent.
[The Undead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUndead): Lich is a [lich](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurLichesAreDifferent).
[Dragon Rider](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DragonRider): Kuja uses the Silver Dragon as his mount. Garland doesn't ride his dragon, but it obeys his every command.
[Our Dragons Are Different](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurDragonsAreDifferent): A white dragon with feathered wings that give it a bird-like appearance.

[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): His name is Japanese is read as Shinryu...which means that he is [THAT Shinryu](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyV), as part of this game's many callbacks. *[Dissidia Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/DissidiaFinalFantasy)* later confirms him to be an appearance of said recurring monster. Thus, the reference in the English version is a case of [Lost in Translation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LostInTranslation).
[Giant Wall of Watery Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GiantWallOfWateryDoom): One of the Nova Dragon's attacks is unleashing a tidal wave.
[Our Dragons Are Different](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurDragonsAreDifferent): It is a dragon that's bigger and stronger than the Silver Dragon.

tropeName: Red and Black and Evil All Over
tropeNotes: [Red and Black and Evil All Over](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedAndBlackAndEvilAllOver): It's colors are this compare to the Silver Dragon's white appearance.
[Weaksauce Weakness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeaksauceWeakness): Despite being a boss, it is vulnerable to sleep. With proper timing this can be used to defeat it without ever allowing it to act.

[Call-Back](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CallBack): To Deathgaze from *[Final Fantasy VI](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVI)*. They have similar names (Downright identical in the Japanese version), and are both flying skeletal monsters.
[Colony Drop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColonyDrop): It's fond of casting Meteor on the party.
[Logical Weakness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LogicalWeakness): Being a demon inhabiting a book, he's naturally weak to fire and holy.
[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): He shares several design elements with the various possessed book enemies from *[Final Fantasy V](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Videogame/FinalFantasyV)*.

[Optional Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalBoss): He is an extra boss that can only be encountered twice. Miss out on both opportunities to fight him and he's [Permanently Missable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PermanentlyMissableContent).
[Paper Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PaperMaster): While hiding inside the book, he'll attack the party with "Paper Storm," launching a swarm of pages at them.

[Permanently Missable Content](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PermanentlyMissableContent): He can never be encountered aside of the two windows of opportunity you're given. Fortunately, he doesn't have any special pieces of equipment, so there's no real penalty for missing out on him.

[Puzzle Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PuzzleBoss): To an extent; he starts the battle closed inside the book, which increases his defense. Attacking then turns the book to a page based on the number value of the damage dealt. When the page that conceals him is found, he becomes more vulnerable, and only casts Poison instead of its more damaging attacks. He will however return to the closed-book state after a number of turns, or if hit with a physical attack.

[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): Tantarian is a corruption of/reference to Dantalion, a Grand duke of Hell who, according to Goetic demonology, is often portrayed as a book-carrying demon affiliated with the arts and sciences. The French version of the game instead names him [Lovecraft](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/HPLovecraft).
[Throw the Book at Them](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThrowTheBookAtThem): He's able to clobber the heroes with the spine of his book.

[Time-Limit Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimeLimitBoss): If you choose to fight him on the first opportunity you're given, considering there's a time limit to save Garnet before she loses her eidolons. Doing so is not recommended unless you level grinded, however, especially considering he's pretty damn powerful for that point in the game.
[Weaksauce Weakness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeaksauceWeakness): Weak to fire and holy. [You know, being a demon dwelling inside a book and all.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LogicalWeakness)
[Cool Chair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolChair): He sits on a stone throne made of stalagmites.
[Defeat Means Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefeatMeansFriendship): He's so impressed by the party's power after they defeat him that he opens his Synthesis shop for them.

[Eyes Do Not Belong There](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EyesDoNotBelongThere): Both his Judgement Sword and his throne have a single eyeball, the latter of which is [red](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedEyesTakeWarning).
[Graceful Loser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GracefulLoser): He takes his defeat so well, he offers the party his services as the Synthesis Master after he's defeated.
[HP to One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HPToOne): His Judgement Sword attack will bring characters down to a digit.
[In the Hood](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InTheHood): He wears a red hooded cloak.

[I've Come Too Far](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IveComeTooFar): He [says this](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LampshadeHanging) during your battle against him should you happen to have already defeated [Ozma](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperBoss) before fighting him.

[Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap): He's notably shocked if you already beat Ozma before fighting him:
QUOTE **Hades:** Wh-What!? You have defeated Ozma!? [I have come too far to retreat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IveComeTooFar). Onward!
[Slouch of Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlouchOfVillainy): Sits in his throne for the entire fight, launching attacks from it.

[Superboss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Superboss): The second hardest optional boss in the game, next to Ozma. Fittingly, he was planned to be the [Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss), but was delegated to an optional enemy. For extra badass points, "Hunter's Chance" plays during his fight, as opposed to the standard boss music.
[Ultimate Blacksmith](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UltimateBlacksmith): He's the Synthesis Master, and allows you to craft some of the best equipment in the game after defeating him.

[Ambiguous Situation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguousSituation): It is either an Eidolon that never truly formed or an Eidolon that's so old that no one remembers what it looks like. Given the nature of summons in this game, if an Eidolon is forgotten, it's original appearance is destroyed. Now it's just a ball of (seemingly) mindless energy.

[Boss-Altering Consequence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossAlteringConsequence): If the friend quest is done, Ozma will no longer evade physical attacks and his shadow resistance turns into shadow *weakness*. Despite that fact, it still casts Doomsday, a spell that deals massive shadow damage against every combatant, even the caster. The result is that Ozma can, in fact, [commit suicide with this spell.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V_2JJJ1SRiM)

[Bragging Rights Reward](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BraggingRightsReward): Like many other *Final Fantasy* superbosses, beating him grants a few: his Tetra Master card, a Pumice that can make Dagger learn the Ark summon (Though said item can be obtained another way), and the Strategy Guide key item, which does nothing but congratulate you when you press Select while highlighting it. ("[You are now invincible. Great job!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LampshadeHanging)")

[Bright Is Not Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrightIsNotGood): This tropes also applies to Eidolons! This *thing* doesn't speak, it just fights, and unless you've already beaten the game chances are it will steam roll you.
[Colony Drop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColonyDrop): Meteor and Doomsday, both which have the potential to be a [Total Party Wipe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TotalPartyWipe).

tropeName: The Computer Is a Cheating Bastard
tropeNotes: [The Computer Is a Cheating Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheComputerIsACheatingBastard): Ozma has a unique AI script that, if its attacked when its ATB bar isn't filled, its bar will instantly fill. Furthermore, while normally commands by enemies and party members will execute in the order they're inputted, Ozma can take its turn in between yours and will do so.
[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): To Gaia in the French version.

[Elemental Absorption](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElementalAbsorption): It absorbs the Shadow element, unless you've beaten the friendly enemy sidequest, after which it becomes a *weakness*, which you can exploit delightfully if you equip all four of your party members with a piece of equipment that either nullifies (Egoist's Armlet) or absorbs the shadow element such as Ninja Gear, Pumice Piece or Demon's Mail.
[Holy Hand Grenade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HolyHandGrenade): It can cast Holy and LV4 Holy.
[Mana Drain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManaDrain): Did you burn out Ozma's MP? He'll just use Absorb MP to steal yours.

[No-Sell](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoSell): He's out of your physical attacks' reach, and absorbs the shadow element, unless you've done the friendly enemies sidequest before fighting him, which makes physical attacks able to reach him and makes him *vulnerable* to shadow.
[Status Effects](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatusEffects): Loves to cast Curse a lot, which will inflict the party with Slow, Blind, and Mini. He'll sometimes use Berserk as well.

[Superboss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Superboss): As per *Final Fantasy* tradition, he's even more powerful than the [Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss), and completely optional. Even the place where he's hidden is optional.
[White Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMagic): It will start casting Curaga on itself when its HP is low.
